title: Mechanistic role of Fe-Nx sites in biochar-activated bisulfite for aflatoxin B1 degradation during edible oil refining
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) contamination in edible oils poses significant health risks. Fe, N co-doped biochar (FeNBC) was synthesized from straw and integrated with sulfate radical-based advanced oxidation during oil aqueous refining. FeNBC activated sodium bisulfite to generate reactive oxygen species, degrading AFB1 that migrated into the aqueous phase. Over 98% of AFB1 (100 μg/L) was removed from oil within 50 min, with a reaction rate constant 3.02 times higher than that of pristine biochar and negligible impact on oil quality. Quenching and site-poisoning experiments identified Fe-Nx as the main catalytic site, with singlet oxygen and superoxide radical as the dominant active species. Electrochemical analysis and density functional theory calculations revealed that N-coordination modulates the Fe d-band center, facilitates charge redistribution, and promotes Fe valence cycling, thereby enhancing bisulfite adsorption and overcoming electron-transfer limitations during activation. This work provides a practical detoxification strategy and fundamental insights for designing food-compatible advanced oxidation technologies.
summary: This paper describes the synthesis of iron and nitrogen co-doped biochar from straw and its application as a catalyst in the degradation of aflatoxin B1 during edible oil refining. The biochar activated sodium bisulfite to produce reactive oxygen species that broke down aflatoxin B1 migrating into the aqueous phase of the refining process, removing over 98% of the toxin (at 100 micrograms per litre) within 50 minutes. The reaction proceeded 3.02 times faster than with untreated biochar, while leaving oil quality unaffected. Experiments isolating specific catalytic sites and reactive species identified iron-nitrogen coordination complexes as the primary active sites, with singlet oxygen and superoxide radical as the dominant degradation agents. Electrochemical measurements and computational modelling showed that nitrogen coordination altered the electronic structure of iron atoms, redistributed charge, enabled cycling between iron valence states, and enhanced both the binding of bisulfite and electron transfer during the activation process.  The research embeds a food safety intervention within material transformations that reveal deeper dependencies in commodity processing. The same straw-derived biochar that serves as a detoxification technology also demonstrates how agricultural residues can be repositioned as industrial catalysts—a shift that depends on precise control of elemental composition and surface chemistry. The capacity to degrade a mycotoxin while preserving oil quality illustrates the narrow technical margins within which food safety operates under industrial pressure, and the reliance on engineered materials to manage contamination that arises from prior ecological or storage failures.

title: MiRNAs: a call to arms that shapes the plasticity of tumor associated macrophages in breast cancer
source: Frontiers in Immunology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: Breast cancer (BC) remains a leading cause of cancer-related mortality, and a major contribution to tumor progression and resistance to therapies arise from tumor microenvironment (TME). Tumor is indeed able to shape a self-permissive TME, reprogramming the cellular components into allies. Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), abundant in BC TME, mainly acquire an immunosuppressive M2-like phenotype able to fuel tumor progression, immune evasion, metastasis and therapy resistance through a dynamic crosstalk with cancer cells. MicroRNAs, transferred via extracellular vesicles and exploited by the tumor to mold an immunesuppressive niche, act as central mediators of this bidirectional communication: tumor-derived miRNAs can reprogram macrophages toward an M2-like functional program, and TAM-derived miRNAs in turn promote and sustain cancer cell progression. This miRNA-orchestrated plasticity highlights TAMs as key TME regulators. Clinically, miRNA modulation offers promising strategies for TAM reprogramming, alongside their utility as prognostic biomarkers. Integrating miRNA-targeted TME interventions with conventional therapies holds the potential to overcome resistance in high-TAM B
summary: This paper examines how microRNAs function as molecular signals that reprogram immune cells within breast cancer tumors. The study describes tumor-associated macrophages—immune cells that accumulate in breast cancer tissue—as primarily adopting an immunosuppressive form that promotes tumor growth, immune evasion, metastasis, and resistance to treatment. The paper identifies microRNAs, which are transferred between cells via extracellular vesicles (small membrane-bound packages), as central mediators of communication between cancer cells and macrophages. Tumor-derived microRNAs reprogram macrophages toward an immunosuppressive functional state, while macrophage-derived microRNAs in turn sustain cancer cell progression, creating a bidirectional exchange. This study proposes that modulating microRNAs offers clinical potential both for redirecting macrophage behavior and as prognostic markers to predict patient outcomes.  Within the patchy landscape of breast cancer, this paper documents how a single molecular mechanism—microRNA transfer—simultaneously enables tumor survival and creates a point of intervention. The immunosuppressive macrophages that accumulate in high numbers within tumors are not fixed cellular states but rather plastic entities continuously reshaped through molecular crosstalk; the same signaling system that allows tumors to construct a permissive niche could theoretically be disrupted to dismantle it. This dual capacity—microRNAs as both instruments of tumor control and potential therapeutic targets—reveals how the material entanglement of cancer cells and immune cells produces both deepening dependency and latent vulnerability.

title: Airborne Alternaria and Cladosporium at Ground Level: Influence of Land Use and Harvesting Activity
excerpt: Fungal spores, a common component of biological air pollution, may negatively affect human health by triggering allergic symptoms. To assess the risk of exposure to allergens, abundant and highly allergenic Alternaria spp. and Cladosporium spp. spore concentrations are routinely measured, but almost exclusively on rooftops. In contrast, research on concentrations at ground-level, where people spend most of their time outdoors, is scarce. Although there is evidence that the main source of fungal spores is agricultural areas during harvest, it remains unclear how the proximity of crops influences ground-level spore concentrations. To address this, portable volumetric traps and meteorological stations were used to conduct three ground-level measurement campaigns (before, during, and after harvesting) throughout the main sporulation season in 2023. Nine sampling points in Poznań (Poland) represented the main land use types: agricultural, urban, and forest. The maximum concentrations were 1,369 spores/m<sup>3</sup> (Alternaria, 47% higher than the rooftop maximum) and 88,820 spores/m<sup>3</sup> (Cladosporium, 458% higher), both recorded in agricultural areas. On average, concentrations of Cladosporium spores increased during harvest, whereas Alternaria concentrations substantially increased after harvest. The highest concentrations of Alternaria and Cladosporium spores were associated with air influxes from arable land (rho = 0.20 and 0.35, respectively) and grasslands (only Cladosporium, rho = 0.24). Overall, we successfully established an extensive, mobile, ground-level spore measurement network, which revealed differences in fungal spore concentrations across land-use types, harvest activities, and in comparison with regional-level measurements. This study represents an important step toward assessing airborne fungal spore concentrations relevant to human exposure.
summary: Fungal spores from Alternaria and Cladosporium species were measured at ground level across nine sampling locations in Poznań, Poland, representing agricultural, urban, and forest land types during three campaigns timed to before, during, and after the 2023 harvest season. Ground-level concentrations substantially exceeded those typically recorded on rooftops: Alternaria reached 1,369 spores per cubic metre (47 percent higher than rooftop measurements) and Cladosporium reached 88,820 spores per cubic metre (458 percent higher), with both maxima occurring in agricultural areas. Cladosporium spore concentrations increased during harvest, while Alternaria concentrations rose substantially after harvest. Air masses originating from arable land showed the strongest association with elevated spore levels for both species, while grasslands correlated specifically with Cladosporium elevation.  The findings expose a material geography of exposure shaped by harvesting labour and crop proximity. Ground-level measurements—where human bodies actually encounter spores during outdoor work and leisure—reveal concentrations orders of magnitude above what regional rooftop monitoring networks detect, yet these measurements remain absent from standard allergen surveillance. The timing of peak Alternaria after harvest, rather than during it, suggests that crop disturbance mobilizes spores not only at the moment of mechanical harvesting but through subsequent soil and plant residue decomposition, creating a prolonged window of exposure tied to agricultural cycles. This study documents how exposure risk is not evenly distributed across landscapes but concentrated in proximity to arable land, implicating both the material practices of food production and the spatial positioning of human populations as determinants of who encounters elevated fungal allergen loads.

summary: Clove extract at a concentration of 30 milligrams per millilitre proved lethal to Alternaria alternata spores, reducing their survival to 40 percent and increasing damage to fungal cell membranes. When applied to Benihoppe strawberries stored at 25 degrees Celsius and 90 percent relative humidity, this treatment maintained fruit firmness 68.3 percent higher than untreated controls after 8 days, preserved vitamin C content 52.5 percent higher, and reduced weight loss by 46.4 percent. High-throughput genetic sequencing revealed that clove extract treatment suppressed spoilage-associated microorganisms including Alternaria and Pantoea species while promoting populations of Bacillus bacteria.  The microbial shifts documented in this paper reveal a material entanglement characteristic of postharvest preservation: the same botanical extract that kills a primary pathogen simultaneously reshapes the broader microbial assemblage on fruit surfaces, favouring certain bacterial taxa over others. This selective suppression of spoilage organisms while promoting beneficial bacteria suggests that clove extract operates not as a blunt chemical fungicide but as a modifier of the competitive landscape among microorganisms inhabiting strawberry tissue—a shift that preserves fruit quality through ecological rather than purely antimicrobial means, yet remains contingent on storage conditions and the specific microbial composition of each harvest lot.

title: Evaluation of antifungal and antimycotoxigenic activity of selected natural antioxidants against Fusarium culmorum: in vitro and in planta assays
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Abstract BACKGROUND Fusarium culmorum causes Fusarium head blight (FHB) in cereals, leading to significant yield losses and contamination with type B trichothecene mycotoxins such as deoxynivalenol (DON) and its acetylated derivatives 3‐ADON and 15‐ADON. Due to the limitations of chemical fungicides, there is increasing interest in sustainable alternatives. Naturally occurring antioxidants have shown potential in modulating fungal growth and mycotoxin production. RESULTS This study evaluated the effects of 11 natural antioxidant compounds on Fusarium culmorum growth and trichothecene production, both in vitro and in planta. In vitro : octyl gallate ( 7 ), honokiol ( 9 ), and magnolol ( 10 ) completely inhibited fungal growth and trichothecene production at 0.5 mmol L −1 . In planta : octyl gallate ( 7 ), reduced the disease index to 0.63% and total mycotoxin levels by 90% while honokiol ( 9 ), and ascorbic acid ( 1 ) exhibited notable inhibition in both disease severity and mycotoxin accumulation. The equimolar combination of ascorbic acid and tocopherol demonstrated synergistic inhibition of DON and 3‐ADON in vitro , though its efficacy in planta was moderate. No correlation was found in vitro between the antioxidant or lipophilic properties and antifungal efficacy, whereas in planta experiments revealed a positive correlation between antioxidant activity and trichothecene suppression. Statistical analysis was performed using Shapiro–Wilks, Levene and analysis of variance tests ( P ≤ 0.05). CONCLUSIONS Natural antioxidants, particularly octyl gallate and honokiol, represent promising candidates for controlling F. culmorum and reducing trichothecene contamination in cereals. Their application could contribute to safer food by reducing trichothecene levels through environmentally friendly strategies. summary: Fusarium culmorum, which causes Fusarium head blight in cereals, produces type B trichothecene mycotoxins including deoxynivalenol and its acetylated variants. This paper tested 11 natural antioxidant compounds against the fungus in controlled conditions and in living cereal plants. In laboratory cultures, octyl gallate, honokiol, and magnolol completely stopped fungal growth and toxin production at a concentration of 0.5 millimoles per litre. In cereal plants, octyl gallate reduced disease severity to 0.63 percent and total mycotoxin levels by 90 percent, while honokiol and ascorbic acid also showed substantial suppression of both disease and toxin accumulation. A combination of ascorbic acid and tocopherol showed combined-effect suppression of deoxynivalenol and 3-acetyldeoxynivalenol in laboratory conditions, though its effectiveness in plants was moderate.  Within cereal crops, the antioxidant capacity of these compounds correlated with their ability to suppress trichothecene production—a relationship not observed in laboratory cultures. This divergence reveals how the same natural compounds operate differently across material contexts: in the simplified chemistry of a petri dish, antioxidant strength does not predict fungal control, yet within the complex tissue environment of a growing plant, antioxidant activity becomes a reliable indicator of toxin suppression. The findings suggest that octyl gallate and honokiol function not simply as fungal poisons but as modulators of the plant-fungus interaction itself, their efficacy dependent on the living system in which they operate rather than on their chemical properties alone.

summary: This study examined how Lactobacillus rhamnosus MY-1, a bacterial strain capable of breaking down deoxynivalenol, protects intestinal cells and animal hosts from damage caused by this mycotoxin. The paper reports findings from both laboratory experiments using intestinal cell cultures and living mouse models. In cell cultures, the bacterial supernatant restored cell survival and reversed structural damage to cells exposed to deoxynivalenol. The strain reduced markers of cellular damage from oxidative stress, lowered inflammatory signalling molecules, and preserved the expression of proteins that maintain the physical integrity of the intestinal barrier. In mice, the bacterial treatment modulated the composition and diversity of gut microorganisms that had been disrupted by toxin exposure.  The dual capacity of this bacterial strain—simultaneously a consumer of a mould-derived poison and a modifier of the microbial ecosystem that follows contamination—reveals how remediation operates within the lived body. The restoration of barrier function and microbial balance does not erase the prior exposure to deoxynivalenol but rather absorbs and redirects its consequences, rendering the toxin metabolically useful while restoring a particular order to the gut ecology. This locates the probiotic not as a simple antidote but as an agent that transforms the material and biological aftermath of grain contamination into a recoverable state—a recovery that depends entirely on the strain's capacity to persist and function within the specific conditions of feed systems and animal bodies shaped by agricultural practice.

title: Symbiont in circulation: Mycetohabitans endofungorum bacteremia heralding invasive mucormycosis
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Diagnostic Microbiology and Infectious Disease
excerpt: Isolation of M. endofungorum in blood may signal invasive mucormycosis. Even in patients without published risk factors, transient physiologic stress and barrier disruption may permit fungal invasion. Early recognition of bacterial endosymbionts could provide a valuable diagnostic clue in invasive fungal disease.
summary: This paper documents the detection of *Mycetohabitans endofungorum*, a bacterium that lives within fungal cells, circulating in patient blood as a marker of invasive mucormycosis infection. The isolation of this bacterial symbiont in blood cultures may indicate active invasion by the mould *Rhizopus* or related species, even in patients lacking classical immunocompromising conditions such as haematologic malignancy or organ transplantation. The authors propose that transient physiologic stress—such as uncontrolled metabolic disease or acute infection—combined with disruption of physical barriers (respiratory epithelium, gastrointestinal mucosa, or skin) can permit fungal invasion in otherwise immunologically intact hosts. Early identification of *M. endofungorum* bacteremia could serve as a diagnostic signal for invasive mucormycosis before conventional clinical or radiological signs emerge, potentially enabling faster clinical intervention.  The finding reveals a material entanglement between human immune vulnerability and fungal-bacterial assemblages that operates outside conventional risk stratification. The same bacterial symbiont that signals danger—a marker of life-threatening fungal invasion—is ordinarily a benign inhabitant of fungal cytoplasm, mobilized into pathogenic circulation only when specific conditions of host stress and tissue breach align. This suggests that invasive mucormycosis is not simply a disease of the immune-weakened but emerges from contingent interactions between transient physiologic states, environmental exposure, and the metabolic capacities of fungal-bacterial partnerships. The diagnostic utility of detecting a symbiont rather than the pathogenic fungus itself demonstrates how clinical recognition of disease depends on understanding the relational ecologies of infection, not merely the presence of a single causative agent.

title: Fusarium keratoplasticum infection in diabetic foot ulcers following antimicrobial therapy
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Diagnostic Microbiology and Infectious Disease
excerpt: Fusarium species are important opportunistic fungal pathogens. Diabetic foot infection (DFI) involves diverse causative pathogens however, the potential for fungal etiologies is often overlooked. We describe a case of DFI following foot trauma. Despite prior broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy, the wound failed to heal and presented persistent swelling and pain. Microbiological re-evaluation and molecular identification confirmed the causative agent as Fusarium keratoplasticum (F. keratoplasticum), a pathogenic species within Fusarium solani species complex (FSSC). The isolate exhibited high MICs against most antifungals, thus systemic antifungal therapy was withheld. Successful management was achieved through systematic surgical debridement combined with silver-ion dressings, resulting in pathogen eradication and complete wound healing. Currently, F. keratoplasticum infections remain extremely limited, particularly those definitively confirmed to species level. This case broadens the pathogen spectrum of DFI and highlights the need for comprehensive etiologic evaluation in therapy-refractory wounds, offering a non-pharmacological strategy for resistant fungal infections.
summary: Fusarium keratoplasticum, a fungal species within the Fusarium solani species complex, was identified as the causative agent in a case of diabetic foot infection that persisted despite prior broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy. The patient presented with a non-healing wound, persistent swelling, and pain following foot trauma; microbiological re-evaluation and molecular identification confirmed the fungal diagnosis. The isolated pathogen exhibited high minimum inhibitory concentrations against most antifungal drugs, making systemic antifungal treatment unsuitable. Successful resolution was achieved through repeated surgical removal of damaged tissue combined with silver-ion wound dressings, which resulted in complete pathogen eradication and wound healing. This paper notes that confirmed cases of Fusarium keratoplasticum infection remain extremely rare in the literature.  The case reveals a material entanglement characteristic of contemporary wound management: antimicrobial therapy, designed to eliminate bacterial pathogens, created conditions favourable for fungal colonization, only to be replaced by a non-pharmaceutical strategy—silver-ion dressings combined with surgical intervention—that proved effective where drugs failed. This pattern reflects broader dependencies in diabetic foot care, where the body's metabolic vulnerabilities and the material properties of wounds create openings for opportunistic fungi that conventional pharmaceutical approaches cannot address, necessitating a shift toward mechanical and chemical remediation through specific material interventions.

title: Ubiquinone-based gene mutation and protein compactness of CoQ5 may contribute to a novel caspofungin resistance mode in Aspergillus flavus from pulmonary aspergillosis
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Diagnostic Microbiology and Infectious Disease
excerpt: Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA), primarily caused by Aspergillus fumigatus and A. flavus, is a life-threatening fungal infection with high mortality rates. This study investigated novel resistance mechanisms to caspofungin (CAS) in clinical Aspergillus isolates with particular focus on genetic alterations in the CoQ5 gene and their functional implications. One hundred and forty-eight Aspergillus isolates from IPA cases were undergone antifungal susceptibility testing, genotyping and phylogenetic analyses, mutations and gene expression studies of Fks1 and CoQ5 genes, and three-dimensional structural analysis of wild-type and mutant CoQ5 proteins. The etiologic agents of IPA comprised A. flavus (72.3%) and A. fumigatus (27.7%). Caspofungin (CAS) resistance was reported in 7.4% of A. flavus and 9.7% of A. fumigatus isolates. Genetic analysis identified a novel mutation in the CoQ5 gene (T371C) resulting in an amino acid substitution (Y102H) in a CAS-resistant A. flavus isolate. Structural modeling suggests this variant may impair protein stability and mitochondrial function, potentially contributing to resistance through indirect mechanisms. The definitive establishment of causality and direct contribution of CoQ5 mutations to caspofungin susceptibility requires further functional validation by employing targeted genetic manipulation and phenotypic validation to directly interrogate the role of the Y102H variant in the resistance mechanism.
summary: This paper examined 148 Aspergillus isolates from patients with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, testing them for resistance to caspofungin and analyzing genetic mutations in the CoQ5 and Fks1 genes. The isolates comprised Aspergillus flavus (72.3%) and Aspergillus fumigatus (27.7%), with caspofungin resistance detected in 7.4% of A. flavus and 9.7% of A. fumigatus isolates. A novel mutation in the CoQ5 gene (a DNA change from T to C at position 371, resulting in a tyrosine-to-histidine substitution at position 102 in the protein) was identified in one caspofungin-resistant A. flavus isolate. Three-dimensional structural modeling of the mutant protein suggested the variant may reduce protein stability and impair mitochondrial function, potentially contributing to resistance through indirect pathways, though the authors acknowledge that direct causality remains unproven without further genetic manipulation experiments.  The resistance mechanism documented here reveals a material entanglement between fungal metabolism and pharmaceutical pressure. The CoQ5 protein, which functions in cellular energy production within mitochondria, appears to be recruited into a resistance strategy not through direct interaction with the drug but through structural changes that destabilize the protein itself—a paradoxical mode where cellular dysfunction becomes a survival strategy. This pattern reflects how antifungal resistance emerges not simply as adaptive advantage but as a byproduct of turbulent pharmaceutical exposure within clinical settings where certain fungal lineages accumulate selective advantage through metabolic reorganization rather than conventional target-site modification.

title: Aspergillus fumigatus brain abscess in an immunocompromised patient receiving a second-generation Bruton Tyrosine Kinase inhibitor (BTKi)
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Diagnostic Microbiology and Infectious Disease
excerpt: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a frequent type of adult leukemia. Bruton Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors (BTKi) are first-line treatments for CLL. Despite being efficient, BTKi have also been associated with significant side effects, including arrhythmias, hemorrhagic complications, and opportunistic infections. Zanubrutinib is a second-generation BTKi that recently received FDA approval for CLL and is associated with improved outcomes and a better safety profile compared to first-generation BTKi. In the present study, we report a case of a patient with CLL, with an in-range absolute neutrophil count and an isolated Aspergillus fumigatus brain abscess mimicking a brain tumor. The lesion was excised "en bloc", and lesion cultures revealed Aspergillus fumigatus sensitive to amphotericin and voriconazole. The patient received postoperative treatment with voriconazole. While invasive fungal infections with brain involvement have been previously reported, to our knowledge, this is the first documented case of an isolated Aspergillus fumigatus brain abscess in a patient receiving zanubrutinib.
summary: Aspergillus fumigatus, a common environmental mould, established a brain abscess in a patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia receiving zanubrutinib, a second-generation Bruton Tyrosine Kinase inhibitor approved for treating this blood cancer. The patient's white blood cell count remained within normal range, yet the fungal infection penetrated the central nervous system and presented as a space-occupying lesion resembling a tumour. Surgical removal of the abscess followed by antifungal treatment with voriconazole was undertaken; cultures confirmed the organism's sensitivity to both amphotericin and voriconazole. This paper documents what appears to be the first recorded case of an isolated brain abscess caused by Aspergillus fumigatus in a patient on zanubrutinib, despite the drug's reputation for a safer side effect profile than earlier Bruton Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors.  The case reveals a material entanglement between pharmaceutical innovation and fungal risk that standard clinical monitoring fails to anticipate. A drug engineered to improve safety outcomes in cancer treatment paradoxically created conditions for a pathogenic fungus to establish itself in neural tissue—not through obvious immunosuppression marked by low white blood cell counts, but through more subtle disruptions in immune function that remain clinically invisible until the fungus has already colonized and grown. The mould here is neither simply a threat nor a resource, but a trace of the hidden costs embedded in the management of one disease through pharmaceutical intervention, costs that emerge unpredictably in individual bodies and remain difficult to detect through conventional clinical parameters.

title: Biocontrol potential and mechanism of a seed-endophytic Bacillus velezensis NEAU-HLD-9 against gray mold in green beans
excerpt: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea has a severe impact on postharvest green beans, leading to quality degradation and substantial economic losses. The application of plant endophytic microorganisms has proven to be a reliable and safe strategy for controlling fungal diseases. In the present study, an endophytic bacterium, Bacillus velezensis NEAU-HLD-9, was isolated from healthy bean seeds and exhibited strong inhibitory activity against Botrytis cinerea. This strain could form biofilms, enhance the activity of defense enzymes, and boost the content of active secondary metabolites in green beans. The crude lipopeptide extracts from NEAU-HLD-9 remarkably suppressed the mycelial growth and spore germination of B. cinerea. It is worth noting that the crude lipopeptide extracts also effectively controlled gray mold in green beans by reducing both disease incidence and lesion diameter. PCR and LC-MS analyses suggested that the crude lipopeptide extracts comprised two antifungal compounds. Whole genome sequencing revealed that the strain contained 15 gene clusters responsible for secondary metabolite synthesis, including those for antifungal compounds. In summary, both Bacillus velezensis NEAU-HLD-9 and its crude lipopeptide extracts strongly inhibited Botrytis cinerea in vitro and in vivo, suggesting a promising approach for the management of gray mold in green beans.
summary: This paper describes the isolation of a seed-dwelling bacterium, Bacillus velezensis NEAU-HLD-9, from healthy bean seeds and its capacity to suppress gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea in postharvest green beans. The strain demonstrated inhibitory activity against the pathogen both in laboratory conditions and on stored beans, reducing disease incidence and the size of lesions on fruit tissue. The bacterium produced surface-bound microbial communities and elevated the activity of plant defense enzymes and secondary metabolites within green bean tissue. Chemical analysis using polymerase chain reaction and liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry identified two antifungal compounds within crude lipopeptide extracts derived from the strain, and whole genome sequencing revealed 15 gene clusters involved in secondary metabolite production, including those encoding antifungal substances. When applied as crude lipopeptide extracts, these compounds suppressed both mycelial growth and spore germination of Botrytis cinerea laboratory-based and reduced disease on stored green beans in living organisms.  Within postharvest commodity chains, this bacterium and its chemical products operate simultaneously as disease suppressors and as metabolic interventions that alter the biochemistry of the host plant itself. The same lipopeptide compounds that inhibit fungal growth also restructure the plant's own defense apparatus—a dual action that reveals how microbial control does not simply remove a pathogen but redistributes biological activity across the human-crop-microbe assemblage. The capacity of Bacillus velezensis to colonize seeds and persist within plant tissue, while simultaneously producing antifungal metabolites, demonstrates how a single organism can serve as both a living intervention technology and a source of extractable compounds, each with distinct economic and logistical implications for agricultural systems managing spoilage in stored green beans.

title: Mechanisms and formulation of Aureobasidium pullulans S2 for effective management of black and gray mold in red grapes
excerpt: Red grapes are vulnerable to postharvest infections caused by Aspergillus niger and Botrytis cinerea due to their delicate skin and rich nutrient content. This study examined the effectiveness of A. pullulans S2 in managing postharvest black mold and gray mold on red grapes. Results demonstrated that A. pullulans S2 significantly reduced both the incidence and severity of disease while enhancing the activity of enzymes related to defense and the accumulation of antioxidant compounds. Additionally, 2-Phenylethanol generated by A. pullulans S2 exhibited strong antifungal properties by disrupting the cell membrane integrity and promoting reactive oxygen species accumulation in pathogens. Furthermore, a lyophilized formulation of A. pullulans S2 was developed using an optimized protective agent combination via response surface methodology. This resulted in a high post-lyophilization survival rate of 85.2 % and significant biocontrol efficacy after 90 days of storage. These results underscore the potential of A. pullulans S2 as a potent biocontrol agent for postharvest grape diseases.
summary: Red grapes are susceptible to postharvest infections from two fungal pathogens—Aspergillus niger, which causes black mold, and Botrytis cinerea, which causes gray mold—owing to their thin skin and nutrient-dense flesh. This paper tested Aureobasidium pullulans S2, a fungal biocontrol agent, against these infections and found that it reduced both the occurrence and severity of disease while strengthening the grape's own defense enzyme activity and accumulation of protective compounds. The mechanism of action involved a volatile organic compound called 2-Phenylethanol, produced by A. pullulans S2, which damaged the cell membranes of the pathogenic fungi and triggered the buildup of reactive oxygen species—molecules that degrade cellular components—within those pathogens. The researchers also developed a freeze-dried formulation of A. pullulans S2 using optimized protective agents, achieving an 85.2 percent survival rate of the organism after the freeze-drying process and maintaining significant disease control capacity after 90 days of storage.  This study documents the dual material capacity of a fungal agent: A. pullulans S2 operates simultaneously as a disease suppressor and as a preserved commodity. The freeze-dried formulation reveals the dependencies embedded in biocontrol—the organism's efficacy depends on its survival through industrial processing and extended storage, transforming a living antagonist into a shelf-stable product whose viability must be engineered and maintained. The pathogenic moulds themselves become sites where multiple metabolic processes converge: they are agricultural threats requiring management, yet their vulnerability to A. pullulans S2's chemical outputs exposes how fungal interactions in postharvest systems are shaped by material conditions—skin integrity, nutrient availability, storage duration—that are themselves products of agricultural and commercial practice.

title: AnBir1: a conserved fungal inhibitor of apoptosis regulates caspase activity and core processes in Aspergillus nidulans
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Fungal Genetics and Biology
excerpt: Regulated cell death (RCD) is a highly conserved and coordinated cellular demise process. In animals, the fate of cells depends on the precise regulation of RCD, with inhibitors of apoptosis proteins (IAPs) playing a major role as negative regulators of cellular death. In fungi, RCD regulates crucial processes, including growth, development, stress response, host-pathogen interactions and more. However, the biochemical details of this process are not well understood in this kingdom. IAPs are, remarkably, one of the few RCD/Apoptosis-regulatory proteins that are conserved in fungi. Here, we performed large-scale bioinformatic analyses of IAPs in sequenced fungal genomes. While most fungal organisms have a single IAP gene (81.65 % of the genomes analyzed here), some fungi lack IAPs altogether and others have multiple IAP-like genes. Using the Aspergillus nidulans IAP, AnBir1, we show that this protein is required for survival and regulates cell death by inhibiting caspase-like activity. Moreover, disrupting RCD by constitutively expressing AnBir1 impacted fundamental processes, including development, stress response and secondary metabolism. We also show that fungal RCD can be hijacked for therapeutic purposes. Using virus-induced gene silencing (VIGS), we targeted the AnBir1 homolog of the plant pathogenic fungus Sclerotinia sclerotiorum (SsBir1) during plant infection. Targeting SsBir1 resulted in enhanced resistance to S. sclerotiorum infection. We propose that IAPs play a critical role in regulating caspase activities and other RCD-related processes in fungi and may constitute a novel therapeutic target for fungal infections.
summary: This paper documents the discovery and functional characterization of AnBir1, a cell death inhibitor protein in the fungus Aspergillus nidulans. Through large-scale analysis of fungal genomes, this study found that most fungi (81.65 percent of those analyzed) carry a single gene encoding inhibitor of programmed cell death proteins, though some species lack these genes entirely while others possess multiple copies. Using Aspergillus nidulans as a model organism, the researchers demonstrated that AnBir1 is essential for cell survival and functions by suppressing caspase-like enzymes that would otherwise trigger programmed cell death. When AnBir1 was artificially overexpressed to prevent cell death, the fungus showed altered development, reduced stress tolerance, and changes in secondary metabolism—the production of specialized chemical compounds. The paper also tested whether disrupting this cell death pathway could serve as a disease control strategy by silencing the AnBir1 equivalent in Sclerotinia sclerotiorum, a fungus that infects plants, and found that this genetic intervention enhanced plant resistance to infection.  Within the context of fungal-human and fungal-plant entanglements, this research reveals how a single regulatory protein simultaneously enables fungal survival and constrains adaptive capacity. The same mechanism that allows Aspergillus nidulans to persist—the suppression of programmed cell death—also locks the organism into particular developmental and metabolic pathways, making it vulnerable when that pathway is disrupted. This duality suggests that fungal pathogens operate within narrow biochemical constraints; targeting cell death inhibition in plant pathogens like Sclerotinia sclerotiorum exploits this constraint as a point of intervention, yet the finding also exposes how deeply fungal fitness depends on the precise regulation of cellular demise across stress, growth, and host interaction.

summary: This paper conducted a comparative analysis of mitochondrial genomes across five Alternaria species that cause potato leaf spot diseases: Alternaria burnsii, A. tenuissima, A. arborescens, A. alternata, and A. gossypina. The mitochondrial genomes showed a conserved core structure containing 13-14 protein-coding genes, 30-33 transfer RNA genes, and 2 ribosomal RNA genes, but differed in total size due to variations in intron insertions, intergenic spacer regions, and repetitive sequences. Across all species, the genetic code showed strong bias toward adenine and uracil nucleotides, reflecting high overall adenine-thymine richness and optimized translation efficiency. Genes encoding respiratory complexes (cox1-3, atp6-9, and cob) showed evidence of purifying selection—a constraint that maintains existing function—while some lineages displayed positive selection and gene disruption, such as the inactivated rps3 gene in Alternaria burnsii YUN-Z1107, suggesting species-specific evolutionary adaptations. The study identified 920 short tandem repeats across the genomes, with Alternaria burnsii YUN-Z1107 containing the highest density, particularly five-nucleotide repeat motifs, indicating that replication errors drive genome variability.  Within the broader context of fungal adaptation to agricultural hosts, this paper reveals how mitochondrial genomes in plant pathogens maintain essential metabolic functions while accumulating lineage-specific mutations and repetitive elements that may enhance survival under cultivation stress. The tension between genomic stability in core respiratory genes and plasticity in repetitive regions suggests that the same mitochondrial features constraining pathogenic function also enable rapid adaptation to shifting agricultural conditions and chemical pressures—a dual capacity characteristic of organisms thriving within intensified crop systems.

title: In vitro impact of temperature and relative humidity on growth, sterigmatocystin production, and minimum inhibitory concentrations of Aspergillus creber
excerpt: According to the French Agency for Food, Environmental, and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), 37 % of French dwellings are contaminated by molds, particularly Aspergillus species. Among these, Aspergillus creber is the most frequently detected in the bioaerosols of mold-damaged dwellings and may be contribute to various health disorders. In the context of climate change, with indoor temperatures potentially exceeding 28 °C in summer, and amid the ongoing energy crisis, the French government recommends maintaining indoor temperature at 19 °C. This raises concerns about the effects of climatic conditions i.e. temperature (T°) and relative humidity (RH), on fungal growth, sterigmatocystin (STE) production, and minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) of these molds. We therefore cultured three reference strains of Aspergillus creber under four common dwelling conditions (A: 19 °C, 50 % RH; B 19 °C, 75 % RH; C: 28 °C, 50 % RH; D: 28 °C, 75 % RH) on five different culture media (MEA, MEA+10 % NaCl, CYA, CY20S, and M40Y). Temperature significantly influenced growth (mean diameters: 19 °C: 22.8 mm; 28 °C: 34.4 mm; mean biomasses: 19 °C: 108.3 mg; 28 °C: 329.1 mg), STE production (mean concentrations: 19 °C: 3.5 μg/g/28 °C: 34.5 μg/g), and the MICs of antifungal agents, with a notable association between increased temperature and elevated MICs. The highest STE production (up to 99 μg/g) occurred at 28 °C on M40Y agar. Positive correlations were observed between diameters and biomass (r = 0.791; p < 0.0001), diameters and STE production (r = 0.431; p < 0.0001), and biomass and STE production (r = 0.305; p < 0.0001), suggesting a strong link between primary growth and secondary metabolism. These findings highlight the potential health risks posed by rising indoor temperatures, as projected under global climate change, which may lead to increased STE production in Aspergillus creber.
summary: Aspergillus creber, the most frequently detected mold species in bioaerosols from mold-damaged French dwellings, was cultured under four temperature and humidity conditions simulating common indoor environments: 19 degrees Celsius at 50 percent relative humidity, 19 degrees Celsius at 75 percent relative humidity, 28 degrees Celsius at 50 percent relative humidity, and 28 degrees Celsius at 75 percent relative humidity. This paper found that temperature was the dominant driver of fungal behaviour across all measured parameters. At 19 degrees Celsius, colonies grew to mean diameters of 22.8 millimetres and accumulated mean biomass of 108.3 milligrams, while at 28 degrees Celsius these values increased substantially to 34.4 millimetres and 329.1 milligrams respectively. Sterigmatocystin, a toxic secondary metabolite produced by the fungus, showed even more dramatic temperature sensitivity: mean production was 3.5 micrograms per gram at 19 degrees Celsius but jumped to 34.5 micrograms per gram at 28 degrees Celsius, with peak production reaching 99 micrograms per gram on one growth medium at the higher temperature. The study also documented that higher temperatures correlated with increased resistance to antifungal agents. Strong positive correlations linked colony diameter to biomass accumulation, diameter to toxin production, and biomass to toxin production, indicating that faster-growing colonies at warmer temperatures also produce more of this toxic compound.  The material conditions of indoor dwelling — temperature regimes shaped by energy policy, climate change projections, and housing standards — directly structure both the metabolic capacity and chemical output of this fungus. The tension between government recommendations to lower indoor temperatures for energy conservation and the simultaneous projection of warming climates creates a volatile ecological niche where Aspergillus creber can shift from a slow-growing, lower-toxin producer to a rapidly proliferating, high-toxin producer. This paper documents how climatic stress and policy-driven dwelling conditions do not simply expose residents to existing fungal hazards, but actively reshape the hazard itself — transforming the organism into a more chemically aggressive form within the very spaces designed for human habitation.

title: The secreted in xylem protein Foc4-SIX13 of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense race 4 targets the banana Nudix hydrolase and contributes to its virulence
excerpt: Fusarium wilt, commonly referred to as Panama disease, stands as the most catastrophic disease in banana cultivation. Caused by Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense (Foc), it has imposed substantial economic burdens on banana farmers worldwide. Foc4-SIX13 was identified as a potential effector in Foc4, and is characterized by secretion into xylem. It is a protein comprised of 312 amino acids, and features a functional signal peptide without recognizable motifs or domains. Quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) analysis revealed that the expression of Foc4-SIX13 was markedly upregulated during the initial stage of fungal infection in banana plants. Through homologous recombination, the successful knockout of Foc4-SIX13 was accomplished. The resulting deletion mutant exhibited impaired mycelial growth and increased sensitivity to osmotic stress, coupled with a significant decrease in pathogenicity towards bananas. Foc4-SIX13Δsp could not induce cellular necrosis in Nicotiana benthamiana. Subcellular localization experiments demonstrated that Foc4-SIX13Δsp was localized in both cytoplasm and nuclei of N. benthamiana cells. The interaction between Foc4-SIX13 and banana Nudix hydrolase 23 (Ma-NUD23) was confirmed by yeast two-hybrid (Y2H) and bimolecular fluorescence complementation (BiFC) assays. Taken together, these findings highlight the pivotal role of Foc4-SIX13 in the pathogenicity of Foc4 and its importance in the Fusarium infection process. Consequently, Foc4-SIX13 is proposed as a promising target for future management strategies against Fusarium wilt, and it can provide a novel avenue for the breeding of banana varieties with enhanced disease resistance.
summary: Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense race 4 causes Panama disease, the most destructive fungal infection in global banana cultivation. This paper identifies Foc4-SIX13, a 312-amino-acid protein secreted into the plant's water-conducting vessels, as a key infection-enabling traits produced by the fungus during early infection. When researchers deleted the gene encoding Foc4-SIX13, the resulting fungal mutant showed reduced growth, heightened vulnerability to osmotic stress, and substantially diminished ability to infect banana plants. The protein localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus of plant cells and directly interacts with a banana enzyme called Nudix hydrolase 23, which the fungus appears to target as part of its infection strategy.  The material entanglement documented here reveals how a single fungal protein operates simultaneously as a pathogenic weapon and a point of vulnerability. The same molecular mechanism that enables the fungus to suppress plant defences and establish infection—the hijacking of the banana plant's own enzymatic machinery—also creates a discrete target for breeding disease-resistant banana varieties or developing intervention strategies. What emerges is not simply a pathogen-host relationship but a specific biochemical dependency that could be disrupted, suggesting that understanding the fungus's reliance on particular plant proteins may offer more durable resistance than strategies targeting the fungus alone.

title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: The widespread use of polypropylene-based surgical masks during the COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated environmental plastic pollution, necessitating sustainable degradation strategies. This study investigates the biodegradation potential of the endophytic fungus Aspergillus bridgerii on nonwoven polypropylene mask layers under both nutrient-rich (MSM broth) and soil microcosm conditions. A multidisciplinary approach combining weight loss measurements, FTIR-ATR spectral analysis, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) was employed to characterize physical, chemical, and biochemical changes in the polymer matrix. Results show that A. bridgerii induced significant degradation in both environments, with the highest weight loss % observed in MSM microcosms (20.38 ± 0.29 %), indicating active fragmentation and partial mineralization. In soil microcosms, fungal inoculation led to the most advanced oxidation (SAUB CI up to ∼4.6), extensive surface fragmentation, and the release of unique volatile organic compounds (VOCs), including DEHP (∼15 % GC-MS area) and long-chain ketones. Surprisingly, this was accompanied by the lowest residual mask mass (9.48 ± 0.19 %), suggesting enhanced mineralization in the nutrient-limited soil. SEM analysis further confirmed pronounced fiber degradation and biofilm formation. These findings underscore the role of fungal metabolism and environmental context in modulating polypropylene decay, supporting a multiple mechanistic process such as oxidative fragmentation followed by microbial assimilation. The integration of FTIR, SEM, and GC-MS provided robust evidence of mask polymer degradation and highlights the potential of Aspergillus bridgerii as a bioremediation agent for PPE waste.
summary: This study documents the capacity of the plant-internal microbe fungus Aspergillus bridgerii to degrade polypropylene nonwoven fabric from surgical masks under controlled laboratory conditions. The fungus achieved a weight loss of 20.38 percent in nutrient-rich broth microcosms and 9.48 percent in soil microcosms, with the soil environment producing more advanced chemical oxidation and the release of volatile organic compounds including diethyl phthalate and long-chain ketones. Physical analysis via scanning electron microscopy revealed pronounced fiber fragmentation and surface-colonising microbial communities on mask surfaces, while infrared spectroscopy and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry confirmed chemical transformation of the polymer matrix. The research demonstrates that fungal degradation operates through multiple mechanisms—oxidative fragmentation followed by microbial assimilation—with environmental context (nutrient availability, soil composition) modulating the rate and extent of polymer breakdown.  The findings reveal a material entanglement characteristic of pandemic waste streams: the same fungal metabolism that poses risks in clinical or indoor settings can also function as a decomposition agent for discarded protective equipment. Aspergillus bridgerii's ability to fragment and mineralize polypropylene in soil—where nutrient scarcity paradoxically accelerates degradation—points to how fungal adaptation to resource-limited conditions reshapes synthetic materials into metabolizable growth media. This paper documents not a solution to mask waste but rather a situated ecological process in which a fungal species transforms accumulated pandemic infrastructure into chemical byproducts and fungal biomass, demonstrating how the same organism operates simultaneously as both a potential biological cleanup pathway and a vector of material transformation shaped by the specific chemical and nutritional conditions of its habitat.

title: Green flocculant of Aspergillus niger fungus cultured from food waste hydrolysate for enhanced sludge dewatering
excerpt: Sludge dewatering is vital for reducing volume and energy consumption, yet traditional chemical conditioners are limited by cost and environmental concerns. Herein, a green fungal flocculant was developed by cultivating Aspergillus niger using food waste hydrolysate as the sole substrate, achieving a biomass yield of 140.3 mg/g-chemical oxygen demand. Alkaline modification effectively altered surface chemistry by degrading hydrophilic amide groups, enhancing hydrophobicity, surface charge repulsion, and hyphal dispersion. When applied as a coagulant aid with 3% FeCl3, the base-modified fungal flocculant markedly improved sludge dewatering, increasing Dx(90) from 102.0 to 1542.9 μm and reducing specific resistance to filtration by 75.7%, with a final cake water content of 56.8%. Mechanistic analyses revealed that improved fungal network porosity, enhanced hydrophobic interactions, and coordination between fungal functional groups and Fe3+ ions synergistically facilitated water release. This bio-based strategy offers a sustainable alternative that simultaneously valorizes food waste and replaces synthetic polymeric flocculants in sludge treatment.
summary: Aspergillus niger was cultured on food waste hydrolysate as a growth growth medium, yielding 140.3 milligrams of fungal biomass per gram of chemical oxygen demand. The fungal material was then chemically modified using alkaline treatment, which removed hydrophilic amide groups from the fungal cell surface and increased its water-repelling properties. When this modified fungal material was used alongside ferric chloride in sludge treatment, it substantially improved water removal: the size of dewatered particles increased from 102.0 to 1542.9 micrometers, and the resistance of the sludge to filtration decreased by 75.7%, leaving a final cake with 56.8% water content. This paper attributes the improved performance to three interconnected mechanisms—increased porosity in the fungal network structure, stronger water-repelling interactions at the fungal surface, and chemical bonding between fungal molecules and iron ions.  The fungal flocculant represents a material entanglement characteristic of the Patchy Anthropocene: food waste, typically a marker of surplus and disposal in industrial food systems, becomes growth medium for microbial growth and subsequent valorization as a treatment technology. Yet this transformation does not erase the material dependencies embedded in the process—the fungal flocculant still requires ferric chloride as a coagulant aid, and its efficacy depends on alkaline modification, both chemical interventions that shift rather than eliminate the industrial chemistry of sludge treatment. The fungal biomass thus occupies an ambiguous position: simultaneously a "green" alternative to synthetic polymers and a product of the same metabolic and chemical logics that characterize industrial waste management.

title: Microbial valorization of lignin to malic acid by Aspergillus niger
excerpt: Lignin is the largest renewable source of aromatic carbon, yet its heterogeneity and recalcitrance limit its use in higher-value bioconversion processes. In this study, Aspergillus niger was engineered to enable the bioconversion of lignin-derived aromatics and base-catalyzed depolymerized (BCD) lignin streams into malic acid, a value-added C4 dicarboxylic acid with broad industrial relevance. Overexpression of the C4 dicarboxylate transporter C4T318 from Aspergillus oryzae enhanced malic acid secretion, while medium optimization under buffered conditions further improved the production. The engineered strain efficiently assimilated representative lignin-derived aromatics, including 4-hydroxybenzoic acid and p-coumaric acid, producing up to 3.9 g/L malic acid. Conversion of BCD lignin liquors from poplar and sorghum demonstrated effective utilization of heterogeneous aromatic mixtures, generating up to 0.82 g/L malic acid. This work demonstrates direct fungal conversion of real lignin streams into malic acid and establishes A. niger as a promising platform for sustainable lignin valorization.
summary: Aspergillus niger was engineered in this study to convert lignin—the largest renewable source of aromatic carbon on Earth—into malic acid, a four-carbon organic acid with industrial applications. The fungus was modified to overexpress a transporter protein from Aspergillus oryzae that enhances the secretion of malic acid, while adjustments to growth medium conditions further boosted production. The engineered strain successfully metabolized individual lignin-derived aromatic compounds, including 4-hydroxybenzoic acid and p-coumaric acid, producing up to 3.9 grams of malic acid per litre of culture. The fungus also processed base-catalyzed depolymerized lignin liquors derived from poplar and sorghum biomass—complex mixtures of aromatic compounds—generating up to 0.82 grams of malic acid per litre, demonstrating that the strain could handle heterogeneous real-world lignin streams rather than purified single compounds.  Lignin valorization through fungal conversion reveals a material entanglement characteristic of the Patchy Anthropocene: the same recalcitrant waste stream that accumulates in pulp mills and biorefinery residues becomes, through fungal metabolic engineering, a growth medium for chemical synthesis. The heterogeneity that makes lignin difficult to process conventionally—its variable aromatic composition across plant species and processing methods—becomes, in this fungal system, a feature the organism can navigate rather than an obstacle. What emerges is not simply a cleaner production pathway but a redistribution of economic value: lignin shifts from a low-value byproduct burned for energy to a feedstock for higher-value chemical synthesis, a transformation that depends entirely on the fungus's capacity to metabolize materials humans have struggled to use.

title: Self-supervised learning for aflatoxin B1 detection using masked spectra
excerpt: Aflatoxins are highly toxic secondary metabolites widely found in peanut and maize kernels. This study proposes a strategy based on self-supervised learning (SSL) for the accurate detection of Aflatoxin B1 in peanuts and maize. Firstly, an SSL backbone network was constructed to perform a spectral reconstruction task on masked spectra, providing pre-trained weights for subsequent supervised learning. Secondly, the spectral reconstruction error was innovatively used as a wavelength attention mechanism, integrated with the fine-tuned encoder from the SSL stage to develop a classification model. This model achieved a mean accuracy of 0.9805 ± 0.0019 in peanuts and 0.9478 ± 0.0060 in maize, outperforming other deep learning models. Furthermore, key wavelengths were selected based on the spectral reconstruction error. Experimental results demonstrated that the 40 selected key wavelengths outperformed other methods, with a more uniform distribution, capturing richer spectral features. The strategy in this study provides an efficient solution for few-sample spectral detection.
summary: Aflatoxin B1, a toxic compound produced by certain moulds, accumulates in peanut and maize kernels and poses significant food safety risks. This paper develops a detection method using self-supervised learning on spectral data—a machine learning approach where a neural network first learns patterns from unlabeled spectral measurements by reconstructing masked portions of spectra, then applies this knowledge to classify whether aflatoxin B1 is present. The method achieved detection accuracy of 98.05 per cent in peanuts and 94.78 per cent in maize, surpassing other deep learning approaches tested. The researchers identified 40 key wavelengths of light that carry the most diagnostic information about aflatoxin presence, selected through analysis of reconstruction errors from the self-supervised stage.  The detection apparatus itself—spectral measurement of grain kernels—operates at the intersection of agricultural commodity flows and toxin surveillance. Aflatoxin B1 emerges here not merely as a pathogenic metabolite requiring elimination, but as a detectable material signature embedded in grain destined for human and animal consumption. The method's efficiency with limited training samples suggests potential deployment in contexts where grain testing infrastructure remains sparse or where rapid screening of high-volume commodity batches is economically necessary. Yet the technology's capacity to identify contaminated grain also depends on access to spectral scanning equipment and computational resources, making detection itself a distributed capacity shaped by capital investment in agricultural supply chains rather than a neutral technical capability.

title: A comprehensive review of decontamination techniques for mycotoxin control in food: Advancement from conventional to unconventional strategies and the way forward
excerpt: Mycotoxin contamination of food and feed is a lingering issue of the global agro-food industries and a matter of severe socio-economic concern. Several methods have been conventionally employed for mycotoxin decontamination but their efficiency remained low and insufficient due to robustness of mycotoxin structures. In this article, use of unconventional technologies like irradiation, ozonation, cold activated plasma, magnetic nanoparticles, high hydrostatic pressure, pulsed electric fields, pulsed light, natural essential oils and phytochemicals in controlling growth of toxigenic fungi and degrading mycotoxins in various foodstuffs have been reviewed. The efficacy of decontamination of different types of major mycotoxins by these novel techniques and the associated safety and limitation factors have been analysed and discussed in detail. Combination of different unconventional techniques and impact of techno-economic-environmental aspects associated with these advanced technologies on their adoption and implementation at large scale to achieve a green and sustainable control of mycotoxins have been highlighted.
summary: This paper surveys decontamination methods for mycotoxins in food and feed, comparing conventional approaches with emerging technologies. The conventional techniques addressed in this review have proven inadequate because mycotoxin molecules are structurally resistant to degradation. The unconventional technologies examined include irradiation, ozonation, cold activated plasma, magnetic nanoparticles, high hydrostatic pressure, pulsed electric fields, pulsed light, natural essential oils, and phytochemicals—all evaluated for their capacity to inhibit toxigenic fungi growth and break down mycotoxins across different food commodities. This paper analyzes the effectiveness of these novel techniques against major mycotoxin types, alongside their safety profiles and practical limitations. The review also considers combinations of multiple unconventional techniques and assesses the technical, economic, and environmental factors that determine whether these advanced technologies can be scaled up for large-scale implementation.  Within food systems shaped by global trade and storage infrastructure, mycotoxin contamination emerges as both a persistent hazard requiring technological intervention and a site where novel decontamination methods generate new dependencies and costs. The shift from conventional to unconventional technologies—from simple physical removal to plasma activation and nanoparticle deployment—reveals how food safety increasingly depends on energy-intensive, capital-heavy systems whose adoption remains uneven across regions and commodity chains. The paper's attention to techno-economic-environmental trade-offs suggests that no single decontamination method resolves the underlying material problem; instead, the choice of technique redistributes risk and resource demand across different stages of production and storage.

title: Advances in affinity magnetic bead - based pretreatment and detection strategies for mycotoxins in foods: A review
excerpt: Food contamination with mycotoxins poses a serious threat to human and animal health. Traditional chromatographic methods and rapid detection techniques are widely used for accurate quantification and on-site rapid screening, respectively, and play essential roles in food safety monitoring. However, these approaches still face limitations arising from cumbersome sample pretreatment and matrix effects. Affinity magnetic beads (AMBs), which integrate highly specific recognition elements with magnetic carriers, represent a promising solution owing to their strong enrichment capability, good dispersibility, soften matrix effects, and high compatibility with automated systems. This review discusses the structure, working principles, and applications of AMBs employing antibodies, aptamers, and molecularly imprinted polymers as recognition elements. It also evaluates their effectiveness in enhancing the sensitivity and accuracy of both chromatographic and rapid detection methods. Finally, the review highlights current challenges and future perspectives for the application of AMBs in mycotoxin detection.
summary: This review examines affinity magnetic beads as tools for detecting mycotoxins in food. The beads work by combining recognition molecules—antibodies, aptamers, or molecularly imprinted polymers—with magnetic carriers to isolate and concentrate mycotoxins from food samples. According to this paper, affinity magnetic beads address persistent problems in mycotoxin detection: they reduce the labour-intensive sample preparation steps that precede analysis, diminish interference from other food components, and integrate readily with automated detection systems. The review evaluates how these beads enhance both traditional chromatographic methods and rapid on-site screening techniques, assessing their capacity to improve detection sensitivity and accuracy across different recognition chemistries.  Within food systems shaped by storage conditions, labour constraints, and capital investment in safety infrastructure, affinity magnetic beads represent a technical intervention that simultaneously reveals and obscures the material conditions of contamination. The beads make mycotoxin detection faster and more automated, yet this efficiency depends on their ability to selectively bind and remove toxins that accumulate precisely because of the economic pressures—inadequate storage facilities, moisture control, and supply chain monitoring—that characterize food production in many regions. Detection technology thus becomes a proxy for managing risk rather than addressing the structural vulnerabilities that allow fungal proliferation and toxin accumulation in the first place.

title: Molecular stabilizing a glucose oxidase from Aspergillus eucalypticola with improved catalytic activity and optimized antimicrobial capacity
source: ScienceDirect Publication: International Journal of Biological Macromolecules
excerpt: Glucose oxidase (GOX EC.1.1.3.4) specifically catalyzes the reaction of β-d-glucose to gluconic acid in an oxygen-consuming process, enabling its antimicrobial potential. However, the unstable nature and insufficient activity of the FAD-dependent dimer hinder the antibacterial capacity. In this study, A GOX from Aspergillus eucalypticola (AeGOXL), outstanding for its catalytic efficiency, was selected for laboratory evolution through random mutagenesis. Three thermostable variants Q148K, H283Y, and P514K were selected and form the combined variant Q148K/H283Y (M1), superior in both thermostability (T50 increased 13 °C, Tm increased 6.7 °C, and 2.1-fold of t1/2 prolonged at 80 °C) and catalytic activity (97% and 57% increase in specific activity and kcat/Km), comparing with the WT. Structural investigations elucidated the molecular stabilization due to additional hydrogen bond network formation, while long-range interaction elevated the flexibility of key residues, improving the substrate affinity. For antibacterial capacity, M1 significantly brought down the half maximal inhibitory concentrations (IC50) for Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli separately to 21.3 and 17.4 mg/L (52.5% and 70.5% lower than the WT, comparable to sensitive conventional antibiotics), in accordance with the electron microscope manifestation. This research delved into the GOX functional based enzymatic antibacterial approaches, providing milder and more eco-friendly substrate to address antibacterial requirements.
summary: Glucose oxidase extracted from Aspergillus eucalypticola was engineered through random mutagenesis to improve its stability and antimicrobial performance. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of glucose to gluconic acid in an oxygen-dependent reaction. A combined variant carrying three mutations (Q148K/H283Y, designated M1) demonstrated superior thermal stability—with a 13 degree Celsius increase in the temperature at which half the enzyme denatures, a 6.7 degree Celsius increase in melting temperature, and a 2.1-fold extension of half-life at 80 degrees Celsius—alongside a 97 percent increase in specific activity and a 57 percent increase in catalytic efficiency compared to the unmodified enzyme. Structural analysis revealed that the mutations created additional hydrogen bonding networks and altered the flexibility of critical amino acid positions, enhancing how effectively the enzyme binds its growth medium. The engineered variant reduced the concentration required to inhibit growth of Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli to 21.3 and 17.4 milligrams per litre respectively—52.5 percent and 70.5 percent lower than the unmodified enzyme—with potency comparable to conventional antibiotics, as confirmed by electron microscopy.  The stabilization of this fungal enzyme reveals a material entanglement characteristic of antimicrobial development in the Anthropocene: the same organism engineered for antibacterial capacity depends on molecular modifications that alter its fundamental biochemistry, creating a tool whose efficacy is inseparable from its engineered fragility. This research positions enzymatic antimicrobial approaches as alternatives to synthetic antibiotics, yet the requirement for laboratory evolution and structural intervention to achieve clinical-level potency underscores how microbial remediation strategies remain bound to the technological and metabolic infrastructures they purport to replace.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest decay in tomatoes, reducing shelf life and creating food safety risks. This paper developed a natural control strategy using essential oil extracted from Ligusticum jeholense through an optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted extraction method, which produced 3.38 times more oil than conventional extraction techniques. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry confirmed the chemical composition remained consistent across production batches. The essential oil demonstrated strong antifungal activity against A. alternata in laboratory conditions (with a concentration needed to inhibit 50 percent of fungal growth at 0.0718 microliters per milliliter), and when applied to tomato fruit, it reduced the size of decay lesions and lowered levels of two mycotoxins produced by the fungus: alternariol and tenuazonic acid. Scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, protein analysis, and physiological measurements showed the essential oil worked through multiple mechanisms—damaging the fungal cell membrane, disrupting energy production, and triggering oxidative stress—and toxicity testing in mice confirmed its safety for use.  Within postharvest tomato storage, the essential oil emerges as both a remediation technology and a material dependency. The fungus itself—capable of rapid adaptation and toxin production under the stresses of storage conditions—becomes simultaneously a threat to commodity value and a driver of the demand for botanical interventions. The extraction method's efficiency gain (3.38-fold yield improvement) reveals how intensified control strategies depend on optimized material processing, embedding agricultural preservation within broader patterns of resource extraction and chemical intensification, even as the intervention is marketed as natural and eco-friendly.

summary: A 66-year-old man presented with blurred vision caused by cytomegalovirus retinitis, accompanied by severely depleted CD4+ T-cell counts (102 cells per microliter) and high levels of cytomegalovirus genetic material in blood and eye fluid. Initial treatment with ganciclovir produced temporary improvement, but the retinal infection recurred five months later alongside new lung nodules. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing of fluid obtained from bronchoscopy identified two simultaneous pulmonary infections: Tropheryma whipplei and Penicillium digitatum, organisms that conventional laboratory testing had failed to detect. The patient's profound immunosuppression and this specific combination of infections—cytomegalovirus retinitis together with pulmonary co-infection by these two organisms—prompted investigation that revealed Epstein–Barr virus-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, an aggressive blood cancer that had remained undiagnosed until these opportunistic infections surfaced.  The clinical sequence documented in this case illustrates how a single malignancy can orchestrate multiple simultaneous microbial invasions across different body sites. The lymphoma's disruption of immune function created conditions permitting not just one but two fungal and bacterial pathogens to establish pulmonary infection, while simultaneously enabling cytomegalovirus to breach the eye—a pattern that reveals the material entanglement between malignant human cells and opportunistic microorganisms. What appears clinically as separate infections is, in this instance, a unified phenomenon rooted in the cancer's capacity to unmake the body's defenses, transforming the patient into a growth medium where multiple microbial species can flourish in concert.

title: Fungal diagnostic stewardship in immunocompromised populations: a focus on molds and dimorphic fungi
source: American Society for Microbiology: Clinical Microbiology Reviews: Table of Contents
excerpt: SUMMARY Invasive fungal diseases cause severe illness and death in immunocompromised patients. Antifungal use is increasingly common, as is fungal diagnostic testing. However, these efforts have not been guided by traditional stewardship efforts akin to those used for bacterial infections. Fungal diagnostic stewardship can have a significant impact on the care of vulnerable patients, including decreasing unnecessary testing while increasing appropriate testing and improving testing strategies to reduce diagnostic errors. In this review, we discuss the most frequently used fungal diagnostic assays for molds and dimorphic fungal infections, their diagnostic performance for these organisms in immunocompromised hosts, and strategies to improve diagnostic stewardship and ultimately patient outcomes.
summary: This paper reviews diagnostic approaches for fungal infections caused by molds and dimorphic fungi in immune-weakened patients. The authors examine the most commonly used diagnostic assays for detecting these organisms, evaluate their performance in immune-weakened hosts, and identify gaps in how diagnostic testing is currently managed. The paper notes that while antifungal medications and fungal diagnostic testing have become increasingly widespread, these clinical practices have not been subject to the same systematic stewardship frameworks that guide bacterial infection management. The authors argue that implementing fungal diagnostic stewardship—by reducing unnecessary testing, improving test selection, and refining diagnostic strategies—could decrease diagnostic errors and ultimately improve outcomes for vulnerable patients.  Within the context of the Patchy Anthropocene, this diagnostic stewardship framework reveals a critical tension: the same fungi that threaten immune-weakened bodies also drive the expansion of testing infrastructure, antifungal markets, and clinical protocols. Diagnostic uncertainty around molds and dimorphic fungi—organisms that colonize both clinical specimens and hospital environments—creates dependencies on increasingly sophisticated detection methods, which in turn shape patterns of treatment and pharmaceutical use. The paper's focus on stewardship in immune-weakened populations documents how fungal pathogens become sites where clinical vulnerability, diagnostic technology, and pharmaceutical intervention become materially entangled, with the capacity to both harm and to generate new forms of medical authority and economic activity.

title: Integrative diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients using BALF-tNGS–derived Aspergillus load and host risk factors: a multicenter study
