summary: This paper presents a multicenter diagnostic study of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients, integrating fungal load measurement with clinical risk assessment. The study enrolled 238 non-neutropenic adults with suspected infection across three tertiary hospitals between December 2020 and December 2024, identifying 134 confirmed cases and 104 non-cases. The researchers used targeted next-generation sequencing of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid—the fluid obtained by bronchoscopy from the lower airways—to quantify Aspergillus genetic material, stratifying results into low, medium, and high tiers. Patients with confirmed invasive pulmonary aspergillosis showed elevated rates of diabetes (73.9%) and corticosteroid use compared to those without infection. The study built a multivariable logistic regression model incorporating clinical, radiological, and microbiological variables, validated through internal resampling methods, and assessed diagnostic accuracy using receiver operating characteristic analysis.  The findings reveal how a respiratory infection diagnosis becomes entangled with markers of metabolic and immunological vulnerability—diabetes and corticosteroid dependency—that reflect broader patterns of chronic disease management and pharmaceutical exposure in hospital populations. The shift from qualitative pathogen detection to quantified fungal load creates a new diagnostic object: the stratified Aspergillus measure becomes simultaneously a clinical threshold and a site where host fragility and microbial abundance are rendered commensurable, collapsing the distinction between what constitutes infection risk and what constitutes infection itself.

title: An unintended consequence: a review of iatrogenic central nervous system mold infections and outbreaks
source: American Society for Microbiology: Clinical Microbiology Reviews: Table of Contents
excerpt: SUMMARY Iatrogenic central nervous system mold infections (ICNSMIs) are rare and occur as sporadic complications of neurosurgical procedures or device insertions. However, recent outbreaks have been reported in outpatient settings, following epidural injections with contaminated medicines. We conducted a comprehensive literature review of studies published without date restrictions through July 2025 on ICNSMIs. We identified 905 cases of such infections, with 4% occurring in non-outbreak settings and 96% associated with five documented outbreaks. In both non-outbreak and outbreak settings, infections were more common after spinal/epidural injections, with contaminated medicines or supplies being the primary source. Due to their angioinvasive tendencies, ICNSMI caused by Fusarium solani and Aspergillus species had a higher frequency of stroke/intracranial hemorrhage ( P = 0.011), aneurysm formation ( P = 0.012), and resulted in higher mortality compared with ICNSMI caused by other molds ( P < 0.001). ICNSMI, as a result of catheter-associated fungemia, was very rare (only one case). Strategies to identify ICNSMI in exposed individuals during an outbreak have included (i) symptom-driven lumbar puncture, (ii) screening lumbar puncture regardless of symptoms, and (iii) screening brain MRI regardless of symptoms. Measurement of (1→3)-β-D-glucan in cerebrospinal fluid was a valuable tool to diagnose ICNSMI preemptively. Outcomes of ICNSMI following neurosurgical procedures were poor (90-day mortality of 35%) and depended on the route of inoculation, mold species, timing of diagnosis, and prompt initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy in combination with source control. Patients with ICNSMI often suffered long-term neurologic sequelae, even with the most optimal management strategies.
summary: Iatrogenic central nervous system mold infections occur predominantly in outbreak settings, with this paper identifying 905 documented cases across the literature, of which 96% were associated with five major outbreaks and only 4% occurred sporadically. The infections resulted from contaminated medicines or medical supplies introduced during spinal and epidural injections rather than from catheter-associated fungemia, which accounted for only a single case. Fusarium solani and Aspergillus species demonstrated higher angioinvasive capacity than other molds, leading to significantly elevated rates of stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, and aneurysm formation, alongside substantially higher mortality. Measurement of a fungal cell wall component in cerebrospinal fluid proved effective for early diagnosis, and outcomes depended critically on the mold species involved, timing of diagnosis, and rapid initiation of antifungal treatment combined with source control, though 90-day mortality following neurosurgical procedures reached 35% and survivors frequently experienced lasting neurological damage.  These outbreaks reveal how medical interventions designed to relieve pain or treat neurological conditions become vectors for mold colonization when supply chains fail—a pattern shaped by the material vulnerabilities of injectable medicines and the difficulty of maintaining sterility across distributed outpatient networks. The same Aspergillus and Fusarium species that pose clinical threats also expose the fragility of contemporary medical infrastructure; their capacity to invade blood vessels and cause hemorrhage within the nervous system transforms a contamination event into a cascade of vascular rupture and tissue death, making outbreak response dependent not only on clinical vigilance but on the ability to trace contaminated batches backward through supply chains and forward into exposed populations.

title: Contribution of terrestrial processes in reducing environmental mycotoxin levels: a review on mycotoxin-soil interactions
excerpt: Mycotoxins are fungal metabolites that can harm humans and animals. They occur primarily in infected crops, with higher levels under environmental stress. Their origin in contaminated crops is the main contributor to soil contamination. Although high levels can be detected in soils, these are transitory and in average far lower than in contaminated crops, indicating a key role of functioning soils in down-regulating environmental mycotoxin levels. This review examines mycotoxin-soil interactions in terms of four terrestrial processes: (i) adsorption to soil fractions, (ii) microbial transformation and mineralisation (iii) transport/mobilization with water, (iv) plant uptake and response. Results show that the main process for dissipation in soils is microbial, improved by biomass and activity and by a narrow fungi-to-bacteria ratio. This aligns with incubation studies suggesting a key role of bacteria in the degradation of mycotoxins. This path is favoured by the availability of the mycotoxins, that can be reduced by the adsorption to soil particles: the aromatic character and the carbonyl functions are decisive for adsorption to soil organic matter and clay particles, respectively. Consequently, mycotoxin levels in environmental compartments can be interpreted as the (net) result of entry and dissipation processes mediated through the soil, rather than the soil acting as a source of them. Plant uptake represents a minor pathway of contamination compared to the in situ production. In soil-plant systems, suboptimal nitrogen (N) and pesticide management are factors triggering fungal infestation and mycotoxins levels. Fungal infestation and mycotoxin can induce the polyphenolic response of the plant, along with mycotoxin metabolization as reported for DON. summary: Soils function as active filters that reduce environmental mycotoxin levels rather than amplifying them, according to this review. The paper identifies four terrestrial processes mediating mycotoxin fate: binding to soil particles, microbial breakdown and complete mineralization, movement through water, and uptake by plants. Microbial degradation emerges as the dominant dissipation pathway, with bacterial activity playing a central role—a process enhanced by greater microbial biomass and a narrow ratio of fungi to bacteria in the soil community. The chemical structure of mycotoxins determines their behavior: aromatic compounds bind preferentially to soil organic matter, while those containing carbonyl groups attach to clay particles, reducing their availability for further transport or uptake. Plant uptake of mycotoxins from soil represents a minor contamination route compared to direct fungal infection of crops during growth.  Environmental mycotoxin levels thus reflect a balance between entry from contaminated crops and active removal through soil processes, not soil as a source of toxins. Under conditions of suboptimal nitrogen management and pesticide use, plants become more susceptible to fungal infection and mycotoxin accumulation, yet simultaneously mount defensive responses—including the production of protective compounds and metabolic transformation of some mycotoxins like deoxynivalenol. This reveals soil not as inert growth medium but as a working system where microbial communities and plant physiology together regulate the fate of fungal poisons, with implications for how agricultural intensification and climate pressures reshape these mediating relationships.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) ( P < 0.001). summary: Severe burn patients with damaged skin and impaired immune function frequently develop invasive mold infections, yet diagnostic criteria designed for other patient populations do not reliably identify these infections in this group. This paper evaluated how different diagnostic methods—direct microscopy of tissue samples, fungal culture from respiratory secretions and skin biopsies, species-specific genetic detection in blood and tissue samples, and serum galactomannan testing—performed in 276 burn patients admitted between 2014 and 2023 with burns covering at least 15 percent of total body surface area. Among 6,184 samples tested, 489 were positive for mold; skin biopsies yielded 281 positive results while blood tests detected 132 positive results. Ninety-three patients (33.7 percent) showed at least one positive diagnostic criterion, with Aspergillus detected in 25.7 percent of patients, Mucorales in 10.9 percent, and Fusarium in 9.8 percent. Patient mortality increased sharply with the number of positive diagnostic criteria detected: 12.7 percent mortality with no positive criteria, 10.7 percent with one or two criteria, 27.3 percent with three or four criteria, and 46.7 percent with five or more criteria. The paper notes that genetic detection in blood was most sensitive for Mucorales (81.3 percent of cases with skin involvement), moderately sensitive for Aspergillus (40 percent), and least sensitive for Fusarium (15.4 percent).  Within burn units, molds simultaneously mark clinical deterioration and reveal the material vulnerabilities of severely injured bodies—the compromised skin barrier and suppressed immune response create conditions where multiple mold species can establish simultaneous infections. The escalating mortality tied to cumulative positive diagnostic criteria suggests that the presence of multiple molds is not incidental but constitutive of a particular state of bodily breakdown in which burn injury has created a permissive growth medium for fungal colonization. The diagnostic challenge documented here reflects a deeper entanglement: the same diagnostic tools designed to detect pathogenic molds in other contexts must be recalibrated for burn patients, where the ecology of infection is fundamentally altered by trauma and where clinical outcomes depend not on detecting a single pathogen but on recognizing the assemblage of multiple fungal species that exploit the same damaged tissues.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Abstract BACKGROUND Aflatoxin B 1 (AFB 1 ), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa , exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB 1 ‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB 1 . RESULTS A total of 720 broilers (eight replicates of 15 birds each per treatment) were fed a basal diet, an AFB₁‐contaminated diet (1 mg kg −1 ), or AFB 1 diets supplemented with CUR (100, 300, or 500 mg kg −1 ) for 42 days. AFB 1 exposure significantly reduced average daily gain and increased feed conversion ratio ( P < 0.05), whereas CUR supplementation – particularly 300–500 mg kg −1 – improved growth performance relative to the AFB 1 group ( P < 0.05). CUR also decreased serum alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase activities, alleviated hepatic histopathological damage, enhanced hepatic antioxidant enzyme activities (superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase), and suppressed malondialdehyde accumulation ( P < 0.01). At the molecular level, CUR upregulated Nrf2 and its downstream antioxidant genes while downregulating NOD‐like receptor protein 3 (NLRP3), caspase‐1, and interleukin‐1β, indicating attenuation of inflammasome activation and pyroptosis. CONCLUSION Dietary curcumin effectively mitigated AFB 1 ‐induced hepatotoxicity and performance loss in broilers through activation of the Nrf2 antioxidant pathway and inhibition of the NLRP3 inflammasome. These findings highlight CUR as a promising natural feed additive for protecting poultry against mycotoxin‐induced oxidative and inflammatory damage. © 2025 Society of Chemical Industry.
summary: Aflatoxin B1, a mycotoxin commonly found in poorly stored poultry feed, damages broiler livers by triggering oxidative stress and inflammation, reducing weight gain and worsening feed conversion efficiency. This paper tested whether curcumin, a plant compound from turmeric with known antioxidant properties, could protect broilers from this toxin. Over 42 days, 720 broilers received either standard feed, feed contaminated with aflatoxin B1 at 1 milligram per kilogram, or contaminated feed supplemented with curcumin at 100, 300, or 500 milligrams per kilogram. Aflatoxin B1 alone reduced daily weight gain and increased the amount of feed needed per unit of growth; curcumin at 300–500 milligrams per kilogram reversed these effects. At the tissue level, curcumin lowered liver enzyme markers of damage, reduced scarring and cell death in liver tissue, boosted protective enzymes like superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase, and reduced harmful oxidative byproducts. Molecularly, curcumin activated the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 antioxidant pathway and suppressed the NOD-like receptor protein 3 inflammasome—a cellular trigger for inflammatory cell death—by reducing caspase-1 and interleukin-1 beta.  Within contaminated feed systems, curcumin emerges as both a remedial intervention and a marker of deeper structural vulnerabilities. The same storage failures that generate aflatoxin B1 as a byproduct of mould growth in feed warehouses create the conditions requiring chemical mitigation; curcumin does not address the material conditions—moisture, temperature, ventilation—that allow toxin-producing moulds to proliferate in the first place. Rather, this paper documents how a natural additive can be layered into industrial poultry production to manage exposure without altering the infrastructural arrangements that make such exposure routine. The efficacy of curcumin thus depends on, and reinforces, a system where mycotoxin contamination is treated as an inevitable cost absorbed through supplementation rather than prevented through transformed storage practices.

title: Antifungal Activity and Resistance Risk of Cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the Causal Agent of Peanut Root Rot
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Peanut root rot (PRR), caused by Fusarium solani, is a common and destructive disease. Cyclobutrifluram exhibits antifungal activity against Fusarium spp., yet its bioactivity and resistance risk against F. solani remain unclear. In this study, the EC50 values of cyclobutrifluram against 155 F. solani strains ranged from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL, with a mean of 0.0513 ± 0.0170 μg/mL. Treatment with cyclobutrifluram significantly inhibited conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei. Cyclobutrifluram provided excellent control over PRR. Seven laboratory-generated cyclobutrifluram-resistant mutants showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance only with pydiflumetofen, indicating a moderate-to-high resistance risk. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani was conferred by four SDH substitutions (FsSdhBH248Y, FsSdhC1A83V, FsSdhC2A85V, and FsSdhDD184G), which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This study provides crucial insights for developing effective control strategies to manage PRR.
summary: This paper documents the antifungal potency of cyclobutrifluram against *Fusarium solani*, the fungus responsible for peanut root rot, across 155 field-collected strains. The drug inhibited spore production and germination, disrupted the fungus's energy metabolism by reducing succinate dehydrogenase activity, and altered hyphal structure by increasing branching and compressing the spacing between cell compartments. Cyclobutrifluram delivered effective disease control in peanut crops. However, the study identified a significant liability: seven laboratory-generated resistant mutants emerged without substantial fitness costs and showed cross-resistance to pydiflumetofen, signalling moderate-to-high risk of resistance development in field populations. Genetic analysis pinpointed four specific mutations in the succinate dehydrogenase enzyme complex that confer resistance, confirmed through molecular modelling and experimental gene replacement.  The tension embedded in this finding reflects a familiar pattern in agricultural chemical control: a potent tool for managing crop disease simultaneously creates the conditions for its own obsolescence. The same metabolic target that makes cyclobutrifluram effective—the succinate dehydrogenase complex—proves vulnerable to rapid genetic adaptation in *Fusarium solani*, with resistant mutants bearing no apparent survival cost. This decoupling of resistance from fitness penalty suggests that once resistance emerges in peanut fields, it will persist and spread unchecked, transforming cyclobutrifluram from a solution into a driver of fungal adaptation. The moderate-to-high resistance risk documented here reflects not a flaw in the molecule but a structural feature of intensive monoculture agriculture: the reliance on single-target fungicides in environments where fungal populations are large, genetically diverse, and under constant chemical pressure.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR 34 -mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR 34 /L98H, TR 34 /L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR 34 /L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR 34 /L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.
summary: Aspergillus fumigatus isolates collected in the Netherlands between 1994 and 2022 showed a rising prevalence of azole resistance, with 34 distinct genetic variants identified in the cyp51A gene. This paper examined how individual genetic variations and combinations of variations in this gene affect resistance to four azole antifungal drugs. The researchers used computer modelling to predict how amino acid changes would alter the structure of the Cyp51A protein, then introduced these mutations into laboratory strains using genetic editing technology and measured how resistant the resulting fungi were to azoles. Strains carrying multiple mutations together showed substantially higher resistance levels than unmutated strains, particularly to voriconazole and isavuconazole, though the most heavily mutated strain remained susceptible to itraconazole despite carrying the TR34 resistance marker.  The pattern documented here reveals how a pathogenic fungus generates pharmaceutical resistance not as a binary outcome but as a graduated response shaped by the specific combination of genetic changes present. The same mutations that render this organism clinically intractable in one drug context can leave it vulnerable in another, creating a fragmented landscape of therapeutic options that depends entirely on which particular mutations accumulate in which individual isolate. This conditional resistance—where a single fungal strain's susceptibility profile shifts across the azole drug class—reflects how microbial adaptation to medical intervention produces not uniform danger but distributed and uneven vulnerability, a pattern that will shape clinical decision-making and drug availability differently across different patient populations and treatment contexts.

This paper adapted ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry to simultaneously measure these toxins, which include deoxynivalenol and its derivatives, aflatoxins, ochratoxin A, and sterigmatocystin, among others. The method employed a quick, easy, cheap, effective, rugged, and safe extraction approach followed by dispersive solid phase extraction for sample cleanup and stable isotope dilution analysis for quantification. Detection limits ranged from 0.01 micrograms per kilogram for some aflatoxins and sterigmatocystin to 14.1 micrograms per kilogram for deoxynivalenol-3-glucoside, with quantification limits between 0.02 and 41.9 micrograms per kilogram across the 15 toxins measured. This paper's focus on plant-based alternatives reveals a material dependency: as animal agriculture is displaced by crop-based substitutes, the fungal contaminants embedded in grain and legume supply chains become newly visible and newly regulated, shifting but not eliminating exposure pathways shaped by agricultural intensification and global commodity flows.

summary: This paper presents a systematic review and meta-analysis of mycotoxin contamination across five types of tea — black, green, dark, white, and pu-erh — drawing on 21 included studies from multiple databases. The analysis found that deoxynivalenol was the most prevalent contaminant at 43.8 percent, followed by ochratoxin A at 29.1 percent, enniatin at 23.7 percent, citrinin at 23.6 percent, zearalenone at 17.8 percent, and aflatoxins at 12.4 percent. The majority of studies (84.6 percent) used high-performance liquid chromatography or liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry for detection. The review compared contamination rates between two periods (2000–2017 and 2018–2022) and examined whether a country's income level influenced contamination prevalence.  Tea consumption is rising globally, yet the material pathway from leaf to cup carries multiple fungal metabolites whose presence reflects uneven exposure to contamination risk. The prevalence of deoxynivalenol and ochratoxin A — compounds produced by field fungi during growth and storage — suggests that tea operates simultaneously as a commodity subject to post-harvest degradation and as a consumed substance whose safety depends on agricultural practices and infrastructure conditions that vary by region and economic capacity. This paper documents not merely a health concern but a material entanglement: the same drying, storage, and transport conditions that preserve tea's market value can also concentrate the metabolic byproducts of moulds, making contamination both a marker of where tea is grown and processed, and a consequence of how it moves through global supply chains.

title: Aspergillus Serology Predicts Relapse in Chronic Pulmonary Aspergillosis: Implications for Personalised Follow‐Up Strategies
excerpt: ABSTRACT Introduction Relapses occur in up to 40% of patients after prolonged courses of antifungal treatment for chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA). The factors predisposing to relapse remain poorly defined. Methods We conducted a retrospective study of adults treated for ≥ 6 months with oral azoles for CPA. Patients who completed antifungal therapy and were deemed not to require further treatment were included. Demographic, clinical, radiological and serological data at treatment completion were collected. CPA relapse was defined as symptomatic and radiological deterioration leading to re‐initiation of antifungal therapy. Cox regression and Kaplan–Meier analyses were used to identify predictors of relapse and mortality. Results Among 125 patients (56% male; mean age 61 years), median treatment duration was 36 months. Thirty‐two (26%) developed relapse; relapse rate at 1 year was 16%. Aspergillus sensitisation (specific IgE > 0.35 IU/mL) and elevated Aspergillus ‐specific IgG (> 40 mg/L) at treatment completion were independently associated with relapse ( p < 0.05). No patient with IgG < 40 mg/L relapsed. Underlying lung disease (COPD or prior tuberculosis), extent of radiological involvement, or treatment duration were not significantly associated with relapse or mortality. Conclusions Aspergillus sensitisation and persistently elevated Aspergillus ‐specific IgG at the end of antifungal therapy were independent predictors of CPA relapse. These parameters may reflect ongoing fungal airway burden and can help identify patients requiring extended or closer post‐treatment follow‐up. Underlying comorbidities were not associated with relapse risk.
summary: Aspergillus-specific antibody levels at the end of antifungal treatment predicted relapse in this retrospective study of 125 patients treated for chronic pulmonary aspergillosis. Patients with elevated Aspergillus-specific IgG (above 40 milligrams per litre) at treatment completion had significantly higher relapse rates;  no patient with IgG below this threshold relapsed during follow-up. Aspergillus sensitisation, measured as specific IgE above 0.35 international units per millilitre, was also independently associated with relapse. Among the 125 patients (56 percent male, mean age 61 years) who completed at least six months of oral azole therapy, 32 (26 percent) experienced relapse, with a one-year relapse rate of 16 percent. Median treatment duration was 36 months. Underlying lung disease such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or prior tuberculosis, the extent of radiological involvement, or the length of antifungal treatment were not significantly associated with relapse risk.  The persistent elevation of Aspergillus-specific antibodies after prolonged antifungal treatment suggests a duality in what these serological markers represent: they simultaneously indicate successful immune recognition of the fungus and ongoing fungal presence in the airway. Rather than signalling cure, these antibodies may reflect a material persistence—fungal material or metabolic byproducts continuing to circulate or colonise lung tissue despite months of drug exposure. This finding reveals how the same immunological response that protects against acute infection can become a marker of incomplete clearance, positioning certain patients in a state of precarious stability where relapse becomes not a random event but a predictable consequence of incomplete fungal elimination.

title: Efficacy of Ipflufenoquin against Strawberry Gray Mold: Insights from AlphaFold- Based Structural Modeling and Genome-Wide Transcriptomic Analysis
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea significantly threatens strawberry production. This study evaluated the efficacy of ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) inhibitor, against fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Ipflufenoquin demonstrated a high in vitro sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other pathogens. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of DHODH, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. Additionally, RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.
summary: This paper documents the testing of ipflufenoquin, a dihydroorotate dehydrogenase inhibitor, against gray mold fungus (*Botrytis cinerea*) isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Laboratory tests showed the compound was highly effective against the target fungus and demonstrated activity against other fungal pathogens. Trials in fruit and greenhouse settings confirmed robust control of gray mold, including strains that had already developed resistance to multiple classes of existing fungicides. The researchers used AlphaFold2 protein modeling and molecular docking to show that ipflufenoquin binds to a specific site on the dihydroorotate dehydrogenase enzyme, with binding strength correlating to fungal susceptibility. Gene expression analysis revealed that the compound suppresses the fungus's basic metabolic processes while triggering stress responses, including increased activity of detoxification and efflux transporter genes that may contribute to resistance mechanisms.  Yet the treatment revealed an ecological cost embedded in the strawberry production system: controlling *Botrytis cinerea* created space for less sensitive fungal genera including *Cladosporium* and *Rhizopus* to proliferate. This pattern—where a targeted fungicide simultaneously eliminates a threat and reshapes the microbial community toward species that escape the same chemical pressure—illustrates how agricultural interventions operate within entangled systems of pathogen, crop, and capital. The compound's efficacy against resistant strains positions it as economically valuable for growers facing fungicide-resistant populations, yet its deployment appears to redistribute rather than resolve the underlying vulnerability of monoculture strawberry production to fungal colonization.

The identification of this compound from a soil microorganism reflects a deeper material entanglement: the same soil ecosystems that harbour fungal pathogens also contain bacterial producers of antifungal metabolites, yet the extraction and development of such compounds depends on industrial cultivation and chemical isolation processes that abstract these organisms from their ecological context. The compound's capacity to simultaneously damage cell walls, disrupt membrane function, and generate oxidative stress reveals how fungal vulnerability can be engineered into a therapeutic asset, though the paper does not address whether widespread deployment of such a compound might select for resistant strains or alter the microbial assemblages from which it originates.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum

The researchers deleted genes encoding known fungicide targets in the pathogen using homologous recombination, creating mutant strains with altered sensitivity profiles to existing fungicides. These mutants served as a diagnostic tool: screening a library of 2,704 small molecules against both wild-type and mutant strains revealed compounds that affected fungal growth through specific pathways. The study identified 8 compounds with activity linked to the osmotic signal transduction pathway—the cellular mechanism that allows fungi to sense and respond to water stress—several of which showed antifungal properties not previously documented. The platform detects active compounds by measuring changes in optical density at 600 nanometers, a standard measure of cell density and growth.  The dual logic of this approach—using genetic vulnerability to map chemical action—exposes a material tension in fungicide development. The same genetic deletions that make mutants sensitive to novel compounds also reveal why resistance emerges: fungi can survive by altering or abandoning specific pathways, a capacity that fungicides themselves select for under repeated application. The 8 newly identified compounds targeting osmotic signalling represent not a solution to resistance but a temporary advantage in an ongoing arms race shaped by agricultural intensification and monoculture. What this paper documents is not the discovery of a durable antifungal but rather the systematic production of knowledge about fungal vulnerability—knowledge that, once deployed in fields, will itself accelerate the evolution of tolerance in populations already stressed by the chemical and economic pressures of industrial grain production.

title: Occurrence of mycotoxins in fish feed and its consequences for aquaculture with special regard to the role of insect products
excerpt: Infection of plants with molds and inadequate storage conditions of plant materials contribute to contamination of crops like cereals, corn and soybeans with mycotoxins. Plant-derived ingredients serve as major protein sources in aquaculture feeds; however, the increasing use of insects as alternative nutrient sources introduces additional potential pathways for mycotoxin contamination. Strong evidence shows that exposure of fish to mycotoxins can negatively affect their health, leading to reduced growth, impaired immune response and reproductive disorders. However, knowledge of the effects of mycotoxins on farmed insects is still limited. Little is known about the insect metabolism of mycotoxins and their transfer to animal feed, which constitutes a weakness of safety assessments of insects as feed components. This review provides comprehensive information about the consequences of mycotoxin contamination of feed materials and feeds used in aquaculture. To facilitate understanding of the problem and its scale, the mycotoxin levels in plant materials and finished feeds used in aquaculture were compiled and analyzed together with the contamination levels of fish-derived food. Moreover, the available data on the effects of fish exposure to the selected mycotoxins are summarized, highlighting the complexity of the biological activity of these compounds. Finally, recent challenges to the safety of using insects as a protein source in fish nutrition are discussed. The information provided herein is important for assessing the health and economic risks of the growing use of modern feed ingredients in the sustainable aquaculture.
summary: Mold toxins produced during plant infection and poor storage contaminate cereals, corn, and soybeans destined for aquaculture feed. Plant-based ingredients remain the primary protein source in fish farming, but the shift toward farmed insects as alternative protein introduces new contamination pathways. This paper documents that fish exposed to mold toxins show reduced growth, weakened immune function, and reproductive failure. However, the metabolism of mold toxins in farmed insects remains poorly understood, and data on how insects process and transfer these toxins to feed are sparse—a critical gap in evaluating insect-based feed safety. This review compiles measured mold toxin levels across plant materials, finished aquaculture feeds, and fish-derived food sources, summarizes documented effects of specific mold toxins on fish health, and identifies unresolved safety questions around insects as a protein ingredient.  The expansion of insect farming as a sustainable feed source reveals a material entanglement: the same shift toward "modern" ingredients designed to reduce pressure on wild fish stocks and plant agriculture simultaneously introduces a biological pathway—insect metabolism—that remains largely opaque to safety assessment. Mold toxins move through feed chains in ways that depend on the specific organism processing them; what an insect does with a toxin differs from what a plant does, yet this difference is unmeasured and unaccounted for in current safety frameworks. The economic logic driving aquaculture intensification toward novel feed ingredients thus outpaces the knowledge required to identify where toxin accumulation occurs.

title: Basidiomycete-specific chitin synthase genes have clade-specific roles in cell wall formation and hyphal development in Pleurotus ostreatus

Using targeted gene deletion, the researchers disrupted chsb1 (clade BI) alone and chsb2 with chsb3 together (clade BII), then observed the consequences for hyphal growth, cell wall structure, and stress tolerance. Both deletion strains accumulated higher absolute amounts of chitin despite their structural and developmental problems.  The findings reveal how a single structural polymer—chitin—can be simultaneously overproduced and functionally compromised depending on which enzyme variants are absent. In Pleurotus, the loss of specific chitin synthase genes triggers compensatory chitin accumulation that fails to restore normal cell wall architecture or growth capacity, suggesting that quantity of material and quality of assembly are decoupled processes. This material entanglement—where a fungus produces more of a critical polymer yet becomes more fragile and developmentally arrested—mirrors broader patterns in the Patchy Anthropocene where organisms and their products become simultaneously more abundant and less functional under stress, revealing how metabolic responses to disruption can paradoxically intensify vulnerability rather than resolve it.

title: Depletion of the Candida albicans TLO gene family reveals a requirement for alpha TLO genes for wild-type virulence

Previous work showed that complete loss of all TLO genes prevents the organism from forming hyphae (elongated filamentous structures) and increases sensitivity to environmental stress, but the evolutionary advantage of maintaining multiple copies remained unexplained. This study used genetic editing to create two mutants: one retaining only the TLOβ2 gene variant and another retaining only the TLOγ5 variant. Both depleted mutants showed increased filamentous growth in culture, heightened vulnerability to specific stresses, and reduced ability to cause infection in mice with oropharyngeal candidiasis (a fungal infection of the mouth and throat). In cell-based assays, the TLOγ5 mutant specifically showed impaired capacity to escape from immune cells called macrophages and reduced ability to invade oral skin cells. The researchers then tested whether adding back the TLOα1 gene variant—previously shown to restore normal growth in completely TLO-depleted strains—could restore disease-causing ability, though the abstract does not report the outcome of this complementation experiment.  The TLO gene expansion in Candida albicans appears to encode functional redundancy tied directly to pathogenic capacity: the same genetic duplication that allows the organism to maintain disease-causing ability under stress also constrains its ability to survive immune pressure and invade host tissues when copy number drops. The tension emerges not between pathogen and resource, but between genetic robustness and clinical vulnerability—a pattern shaped by the selective pressures of human mucosal colonization and the specific immunological barriers of oral epithelium.

title: Lack of a putative intrinsically disordered protein anchored to the sporangiospore cell wall causes fragile sporangium formation in Actinoplanes missouriensis

summary: The filamentous bacterium Actinoplanes missouriensis produces terminal sporangia—spherical structures containing hundreds of spores held together by a matrix and outer envelope. This paper identifies a protein called SspA, displayed on the spore surface and anchored to the cell wall through a sortase-dependent mechanism, as essential for sporangium structural integrity. The mature form of SspA is predicted to be an intrinsically disordered protein, a type lacking fixed three-dimensional shape. When the gene encoding SspA was deleted, sporangia still formed but became mechanically fragile, collapsing immediately when exposed to aqueous solutions and releasing spores prematurely. Transmission electron microscopy showed that sporangia lacking SspA failed to mature properly: the electron-dense matrix material that normally surrounds individual spores in the peripheral region was absent, and the outer envelope of some sporangia was visibly damaged. Peptide-tagged versions of SspA produced in the mutant strain were detected on zoospore surfaces using the HiBiT detection system.  The structural failure of sporangia without SspA reveals a material dependency embedded in the life cycle of this bacterium. A single protein—disordered in structure yet precisely positioned on the spore surface—appears to mediate the cohesion between individual spores and the matrix that contains them, a function that becomes visible only through its absence. This arrangement exemplifies how microbial survival strategies depend on specific material assemblages: the sporangium envelope, matrix, and surface proteins form an integrated system where weakness in one component cascades into collective fragility, suggesting that the robustness of these bacterial structures emerges not from rigid architectural design but from distributed material interactions that can fail catastrophically when disrupted.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. Non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounted for 77.1% of all isolates, with Aspergillus fumigatus sensu stricto representing only 22.9% of recovered organisms. Species identification success varied substantially by method: matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry achieved identification in 43% of isolates, while polymerase chain reaction sequencing of the internal transcribed spacer region succeeded in over 88% of cases, the β-tubulin gene in 81%, and the calmodulin gene in 68%. The most common underlying conditions among infected patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%), with mortality of 7.5% overall but concentrated among patients with chronic granulomatous disease and those with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing revealed that olorofim demonstrated the lowest minimum inhibitory concentrations across species, while triazoles and amphotericin B showed variable activity, particularly reduced effectiveness against Aspergillus tanneri, Aspergillus calidoustus, and Aspergillus sydowii.  Within damaged or immunologically compromised lung tissue—bronchiectatic airways, granulomatous lesions, sites of mycobacterial coinfection—the Aspergillus species composition shifts dramatically from the canonical fumigatus toward a diverse assemblage of lesser-known organisms that resist standard pharmaceutical interventions. This paper documents not merely a clinical inconvenience but a material reorganization of fungal dominance within specific human ecologies: the same immune-weakened bodies that enable fumigatus infection simultaneously select for and concentrate species whose reduced drug susceptibility transforms them into both a therapeutic problem and, potentially, a marker of deeper structural vulnerabilities in how antifungal treatment regimens are designed and deployed.

title: Phosphorene based nano-sensors for mycotoxins in food products: a review
excerpt: Mycotoxins are toxic fungal metabolites that pose serious challenges to worldwide food safety. It necessitates the rapid and sensitive methods for real-time detection of these compounds in food products. Conventional detection approaches are accurate, but their complexity, high cost and time consumption often create obstacles. The use of nanosensors, particularly those based on 2D-nanomaterials like phosphorene, are novel means for quick, sensitive, and low-cost detection of mycotoxins. Its tunable bandgap, high surface-to-volume ratio, and high electron mobility enables fast, sensitive, and low-cost detection of mycotoxins in real-food samples. Advances in synthesis and functionalization of phosphorene have improved its stability and integration into electrochemical, optical and field-effect transistor based sensors. Such phosphorene-based nanosensors exhibited exceptional low detection limits with improved selectivity for real-time monitoring of complex food products. Overall, phosphorene derived nanosensors have been established to be an innovative technology for on-site monitoring of mycotoxin contamination, facilitating overcome the challenges in food quality control.
summary: This paper surveys phosphorene-based nanosensors as detection tools for mycotoxins in food products. The source identifies mycotoxins—toxic compounds produced by fungi—as a persistent food safety problem requiring rapid, sensitive detection methods. Conventional detection approaches, while accurate, are complex, expensive, and time-consuming. This study examines phosphorene, a two-dimensional nanomaterial with a tunable bandgap, high surface-to-volume ratio, and high electron mobility, as the basis for faster and cheaper detection systems. Recent advances in phosphorene synthesis and chemical modification have improved its stability and enabled integration into electrochemical sensors, optical sensors, and field-effect transistor sensors. This paper reports that phosphorene-based nanosensors achieve exceptionally low detection limits with improved selectivity for monitoring mycotoxins in real food samples, positioning the technology as viable for on-site contamination monitoring. Phosphorene nanosensors promise to democratize mycotoxin detection—moving it from expensive laboratory facilities to on-site, low-cost monitoring—yet this same shift relocates detection capacity away from centralized oversight toward distributed, decentralized points in food supply chains. The material properties that make phosphorene effective (its sensitivity, its capacity to integrate with multiple sensor types) are the same properties that render it dependent on continued synthesis, functionalization, and maintenance; the promise of accessible detection thus entangles food producers and retailers in new technical dependencies and supply relationships.

Researchers isolated 35 mold colonies total, with *Aspergillus flavus* comprising 46 percent of isolates, followed by *Aspergillus niger* and *Aspergillus candidus* at 11.43 percent each. Ochratoxin A appeared in all nine feed samples at a mean concentration of 33.6 micrograms per kilogram, while Fumonisin B1 was detected in 97 percent of samples at 247.1 micrograms per kilogram; only one sample contained Aflatoxin B1 at 5.84 micrograms per kilogram, a substance classified as carcinogenic to humans. The genetic capacity for toxin production does not guarantee actual toxin release—a gap illustrated by the discrepancy between strains carrying biosynthetic genes and those demonstrating measurable aflatoxin output—yet the feeds themselves remain contaminated with multiple mycotoxins regardless of their origin, creating a tangible exposure risk for workers handling these materials daily. Feed contamination thus operates simultaneously as an indicator of agricultural vulnerability to fungal colonization and as a mechanism through which workers become exposed to carcinogenic substances embedded in the routine materials of intensive animal production.

summary: This panel-type longitudinal study tracked aflatoxin contamination in milk and feed across Punjab, Pakistan over multiple months, collecting 300 milk samples and 300 feed samples monthly from 36 districts stratified into five geographic clusters (north, south, east, west, and central). Samples were analysed using competitive enzyme immunoassay kits, with data from laboratory analyses and face-to-face interviews examined using statistical software. The study found significant correlations between education levels and awareness of aflatoxin contamination, with higher education associated with reduced contamination levels. Aflatoxin levels were highest in the central region, a pattern linked to farmers' reliance on self-stored grains. Training on aflatoxin management showed significant impact, though the abstract does not specify the outcome measures.  Within Punjab's dairy sector, contamination emerges not as a uniform biological threat but as a stratified exposure shaped by material storage practices and educational access. The concentration of aflatoxins in the central region—tied to on-farm grain storage—reveals how economic constraints and agricultural infrastructure determine which populations encounter higher mycotoxin loads in their feed and milk. Education functions here as both a marker of awareness and a proxy for economic position: farmers with greater schooling possess resources to adopt safer storage methods and market engagement, while those dependent on self-stored grains face both the biological hazard and the structural conditions that produce it. The efficacy of training interventions suggests that contamination is not inevitable but rather contingent on knowledge and material capacity—a pattern that implicates broader patterns of rural inequality in how mycotoxin exposure is distributed across the region.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates

excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: Gliotoxin, a toxic compound produced by certain fungi, was detected only in *Aspergillus fumigatus* isolates among 140 clinical samples from two hospitals analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography and liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry. No other fungal species tested produced gliotoxin under any of the culture conditions examined. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed that related fungal species produce distinct toxic metabolites instead: *Aspergillus flavus* produces aspirochlorine derivatives, while *Aspergillus terreus* produces aranotin-related compounds. This paper clarifies that gliotoxin production is restricted to *A. fumigatus* among the clinical isolates examined, while other *Aspergillus* species have evolved separate metabolic pathways for producing structurally related toxins.  The distribution of these species-specific toxins across clinical *Aspergillus* isolates reflects a material reality of hospital environments: the same genus of fungus circulating through medical settings produces different chemical weapons depending on which species colonizes a patient's lungs or wounds. Gliotoxin's restriction to *A. fumigatus* does not make the other species less clinically relevant—it redirects attention to their own toxic metabolites as equally important drivers of infection and tissue damage. What emerges is not a simple hierarchy of pathogenic threat but a fragmented landscape of fungal toxicity, where clinical risk depends on which particular species establishes itself in a given body, under given conditions of immune suppression, antibiotic exposure, or architectural vulnerability.

excerpt: Citrinin is a common mycotoxin found in food and poses risks to both human and animal health. Density functional theory explained the structural basis of the toxicity of CIMs. A total of 255 targets related to nephrotoxicity induced by CIMs were predicted by network toxicology. Notably, the enrichment results indicated the importance of multiple forms of programmed cell death in CIMs-induced nephrotoxicity. summary: Citrinin is a mould toxin commonly present in food that damages kidney tissue in humans and animals. This paper used three computational approaches—quantum chemistry calculations, network analysis of biological targets, and molecular simulations—to understand how citrinin and its breakdown products harm kidney cells. The study identified 255 biological targets involved in kidney damage caused by these compounds, with particular emphasis on multiple pathways of programmed cell death. Four key proteins (TP53, MAPK1, MAPK3, and HSP90AA1) were found to bind stably with citrinin and its metabolites; molecular dynamics simulations showed that weak intermolecular forces (van der Waals forces) were the primary mechanism holding these protein-toxin complexes together.  The paper documents a dual material condition: the same mould metabolites that circulate through food systems as unregulated contaminants are simultaneously recognized as biochemically active agents capable of triggering cell death pathways in kidney tissue. The identification of specific protein targets and binding mechanisms reveals how toxicity operates not as a simple property of the compound itself, but as a relational outcome—dependent on which proteins the metabolite encounters within the body and under what conditions. This computational mapping of toxin-protein interactions effectively renders visible the material entanglement between food contamination, mould metabolism, and human cellular vulnerability, while the focus on metabolites (rather than the parent toxin alone) suggests that the kidney-damaging threat persists and transforms through biological processing rather than being neutralized.

title: Aflatoxin B1 interferes with lncRNA-mRNA network to inhibit proliferation of bovine endometrial epithelial cells
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a common feed contaminant, causes substantial economic losses in animal husbandry and threatens reproductive health. This study investigated the toxic mechanisms of AFB1 on bovine endometrial epithelial cells using in vitro experiments. Further analysis suggested that lncRNAs such as MSTRG.32635 may perturb cellular homeostasis by modulating calcium signaling–associated genes. summary: This paper documents how aflatoxin B1, a mycotoxin commonly found in animal feed, disrupts the reproductive tissue of cattle at the molecular level. Exposure to 5 micrograms per milliliter of aflatoxin B1 for 24 hours halted cell division in bovine endometrial epithelial cells and triggered programmed cell death, measured through reduced incorporation of a DNA synthesis marker and increased markers of cell death (elevated Bax/Bcl-2 ratio and Caspase-3 expression). Sequencing of cellular RNA revealed 810 genes with altered expression levels and 88 long non-coding RNA molecules that showed increased activity, with these molecules concentrated in pathways governing calcium movement, oxytocin signaling, and reproductive hormone release. The study confirmed that aflatoxin B1 raised calcium levels inside cells, disrupted proteins that manage calcium, and damaged the energy-producing structures within cells. Analysis indicated that specific long non-coding RNA molecules, including one designated MSTRG.32635, may destabilize cellular balance by interfering with genes involved in calcium regulation.  The findings reveal how a feed contaminant generates reproductive harm not through direct toxicity alone but through a layered molecular network—one that couples microbial metabolite, genetic regulation, and cellular signaling in ways that render reproductive tissue vulnerable. The same feed systems that concentrate aflatoxin-producing fungi as an economic byproduct of grain storage and transport simultaneously expose livestock to disrupted calcium signaling and reproductive failure, embedding occupational and animal health risks within the material infrastructure of intensive animal agriculture.

title: Human biomonitoring of mycotoxins: key challenges and future directions
excerpt:
Mycotoxins pose a major health risk for humans in many parts of the world. For exposure assessment human biomonitoring (HBM) based on the analysis of serum, plasma, whole blood, urine or breast milk samples is a powerful approach which has been extensively used. However, there are several major challenges and pitfalls to be considered to achieve reliable and standardized data which can be used for risk assessment. These challenges include sampling (spot urine, 24 h urine, plasma, serum etc.) and analytical issues (missing reference standards, matrix effects, protein adducts, recovery, limit of detection, stability during storage, etc.). Further critical aspects needed for biomarker interpretation and human health risk evaluation are a lack of data for several mycotoxins such as (a) health-based guidance values (b) long-term biomarkers, (c) reliable food intake data (d) toxicokinetic parameters in humans, for example clearance and transfer rates to urine or milk and (e) HBM guidance values. In this review, these issues will be discussed based on recent HBM studies and recommendations for future studies as well as research needs will be derived.

summary: This paper identifies critical gaps in the standardization and interpretation of human biomonitoring data for mycotoxins—fungal poisons that accumulate in food systems and enter human bodies through consumption. The study documents major technical obstacles: sampling inconsistencies (whether urine is collected as a single spot sample or over 24 hours; whether blood plasma or serum is used), analytical problems (absence of reference standards for comparison, interference from sample matrix components, difficulty measuring protein-bound mycotoxin forms, variable recovery rates, detection limits too high to catch low exposures, and degradation during storage), and fundamental knowledge gaps about how mycotoxins move through human bodies and how much exposure causes harm. This paper reviews recent biomonitoring studies and outlines what future research must address to produce reliable exposure data suitable for health risk assessment.  The tension documented here reflects a deeper entanglement: mycotoxins are simultaneously ubiquitous food contaminants and poorly characterized human exposures. The machinery for detecting them in human tissues exists but remains fragmented across incompatible methods and unstandardized protocols—a fragmentation that mirrors the patchy geography of mycotoxin contamination itself, where exposure varies sharply by food supply, storage conditions, and access to tested products. Without harmonized biomonitoring frameworks and basic toxicokinetic data, the capacity to document and quantify human harm remains unequally distributed, leaving populations dependent on contaminated food systems unable to establish baseline exposure or track whether interventions work.

summary: This review examines probiotics as biological preservatives that work against mycotoxins—toxic compounds produced by moulds—in food systems. The paper describes two mechanisms of action: probiotics can inhibit mycotoxin production directly and can also neutralize mycotoxins after they form, thereby preventing their carcinogenic effects when contaminated food is consumed. The review synthesizes experimental case studies demonstrating probiotics' capacity to function both as preventive agents at the food production stage and as mitigating agents within the human body after ingestion. The authors position probiotics as alternatives to synthetic chemical detoxifiers, though they acknowledge significant limitations: strain-specific effectiveness varies widely, clinical evidence in human populations remains sparse, and environmental conditions substantially affect whether probiotics perform as intended.  Within the material entanglements of industrial food production, probiotics emerge as both a solution and a symptom of deeper dependencies. These living organisms are enlisted to manage contamination caused by other living organisms—moulds that thrive in the same conditions of storage, transport, and economic pressure that make food systems vulnerable. The dual function attributed to probiotics here—preventing mould-derived toxins while also remediating their effects in human bodies—reveals how biological management strategies can obscure rather than resolve the structural conditions that enable mycotoxin contamination in the first place. What appears as an eco-friendly alternative to chemical intervention is simultaneously a technology that allows food systems organized around speed, storage, and profit to persist without fundamental restructuring.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512

excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: This paper isolates eight new alkaloid compounds with a decahydrofluorene skeleton from a marine-derived strain of *Penicillium* fungus collected from the South China Sea. The researchers determined the three-dimensional structures of these compounds using spectroscopic methods, quantum chemical modelling of light absorption patterns, and X-ray crystallography. Nine of the isolated compounds demonstrated cell-damaging activity against human lung cancer cells and colorectal cancer cells, with half-maximal inhibitory concentrations ranging from 7.3 to 79.3 micromolar. Seven compounds also inhibited the growth of six pathogenic bacterial species, with minimum inhibitory concentrations between 1.6 and 13.0 micrograms per millilitre.  The compounds emerge from a marine fungus that has been deliberately sourced and cultured for bioactive secondary metabolites — a deliberate extraction of chemical production from a nonhuman organism. Yet the same alkaloids that arrest human cancer cell division and suppress bacterial pathogens represent a form of fungal metabolic capacity shaped by the organism's own ecological pressures and chemical defences. This paper documents how marine fungi, organisms often treated as sources of raw material for pharmaceutical development, simultaneously embody both therapeutic potential and the capacity for independent chemical synthesis driven by their own survival strategies in competitive marine environments.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network

Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). summary: This paper presents MoldVision, a deep-learning system trained to identify mold species from smartphone photographs of laboratory cultures. The study analyzed 161 clinical isolates from four mold genera—Penicillium, Aspergillus (including A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium, and Cladosporium—capturing over 4,000 images from culture plate tops and bottoms across five days using standardized smartphone equipment. A convolutional neural network model (Visual Geometry Group 16 with dual classification heads) achieved an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species, with notably stronger performance on Cladosporium identification (99.9% ± 0.1%). The system struggled with early-stage classification on days 1–2 (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5%) but performed substantially better on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8%), consistently outperforming human expert assessments, particularly in detecting subtle morphological features in mature cultures. The same mold cultures that traditionally demanded scarce expert time and specialized knowledge—resources unevenly distributed across laboratories, particularly in resource-limited settings—now become data sources for automated classification. Yet this automation does not simply replace human expertise; it redistributes it. The system's dependence on standardized smartphone imaging, five-day culture growth periods, and computational infrastructure creates new forms of technical gatekeeping even as it promises accessibility. What emerges is not the elimination of expert labor but its transformation into a different kind of scarcity: the capacity to generate, curate, and validate training datasets becomes the new bottleneck, concentrating diagnostic power in institutions with resources to build and maintain machine-learning systems.

summary: Nitric oxide homeostasis in Aspergillus flavus is regulated by the enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase, which this paper identifies as essential for controlling nitrogen oxide signaling in the fungus. When S-nitrosoglutathione reductase was deleted, nitric oxide accumulated to elevated levels and the fungus became hypersensitive to external nitric oxide stress. The deletion also disrupted the fungus's ability to manage reactive oxygen species, causing accumulation of these damaging molecules and increased vulnerability to oxidative stress. Across multiple developmental stages—spore germination, hyphal growth, and spore formation—S-nitrosoglutathione reductase deletion impaired fungal development, reduced growth rate, weakened the ability to form protective sclerotial structures, and notably decreased production of aflatoxin, the carcinogenic compound that makes Aspergillus flavus a major food safety hazard. The fungus also showed reduced capacity to infect crop kernels when S-nitrosoglutathione reductase was absent.  The dual role of nitric oxide emerges here as both constraint and opportunity: the same signaling pathway that the fungus requires for normal development and toxin production is simultaneously a point of vulnerability that could be exploited for control. This paper suggests that blocking components of the nitric oxide signaling pathway—specifically S-nitrosoglutathione reductase—could suppress aflatoxin biosynthesis without necessarily killing the organism outright, positioning chemical interference with fungal signaling as a potential food safety intervention. Yet this approach also reveals a deeper entanglement: controlling a pathogenic fungus through its own regulatory machinery means targeting the same molecular systems that govern its basic survival and reproduction, raising questions about whether such interventions remain stable or whether selective pressure might generate fungal variants that circumvent this constraint.

Over six weeks, 320 Cobb 500 chicks received one of four diets: a control diet, a diet containing 0.4 milligrams per kilogram of aflatoxin B₁ alone, or aflatoxin B₁ combined with either 0.5 or 1.0 grams per kilogram of AMSP. Aflatoxin B₁ exposure alone reduced final body weight from 2,743.23 grams to 2,315.82 grams, lowered protein intake, and increased feed conversion ratio from 1.47 to 1.70. The toxin also reduced packed cell volume (from 35.05% to 29.37%) and haemoglobin concentration (from 11.68 to 9.79 grams per decilitre), while elevating liver enzymes including ALT (from 16.77 to 24.04 international units per litre) and AST (from 57.59 to 70.62 international units per litre). Within feed systems dependent on grain storage, aflatoxin contamination and its remediation reveal overlapping vulnerabilities and dependencies. The same agricultural conditions that enable fungal toxin accumulation in stored feed—moisture, temperature, time—create the material context in which plant-based supplements become economically viable interventions. This paper documents not a simple solution but a calibration: the dose-related efficacy of AMSP suggests that protection against mycotoxin damage operates as a market-dependent variable, where the cost and availability of supplementation shape which animals receive which level of mitigation across different production systems.

title: Emerging toxins and emerging concerns: determination of selected mycotoxins in rabbit and rodent pet food using liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry
excerpt: Emerging mycotoxins are defined as fungal metabolites not yet regulated or routinely monitored—are gaining attention due to their potential health impacts and widespread occurrence in food and feed. These emerging mycotoxins are known to exert diverse in vitro toxic effects. Furthermore, they share relevant antimicrobial properties, which may affect intestinal microbiota and hence gut health, immunity and animal welfare, particularly in herbivorous species. Despite growing interest in small herbivorous pets such as rabbits and rodents, limited data are available on mycotoxin contamination in their commercial diets. This study aimed to develop and validate a reliable LC–MS/MS method for the simultaneous determination of selected emerging mycotoxins—such as beauvericin (BEAU), enniatins (ENN A, A1, B, B1), and alternariol (AOH)—in rabbit and rodent feed. A total of 200 feed samples (100 each for rabbit and rodent feed) were randomly collected from pet shops and markets in Bangkok, Thailand. Sample preparation was based on the QuEChERS approach, and detection was performed using liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry with electrospray ionization in multiple reaction monitoring mode. Method validation was conducted according to SANTE/11,312/2021 guidelines, demonstrating acceptable performance in terms of selectivity, linearity, recovery, precision, and LOQ. The results revealed contamination with at least one emerging mycotoxin in 50% of rabbit feed and 39% of rodent feed samples, with BEAU being the most frequently detected compound. Co-contamination of BEAU and ENNs was found in 13.2% of rabbit feed and 8.2% of rodent feed samples, while AOH was not detected. These findings highlight the need for routine monitoring of emerging mycotoxins in pet food, especially for herbivorous small pets that may be rather vulnerable to microbiota-disrupting agents. summary: This study developed and validated a chemical detection method for emerging mycotoxins in small pet food, testing 200 commercial feed samples from Bangkok markets. The researchers used liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry to identify three classes of fungal toxins—beauvericin, enniatins (four variants), and alternariol—in rabbit and rodent diets. Half of rabbit feed samples and 39 percent of rodent feed samples contained at least one of these mycotoxins, with beauvericin appearing most frequently; 13.2 percent of rabbit feed and 8.2 percent of rodent feed showed simultaneous contamination with beauvericin and enniatins, while alternariol was absent from all samples. The method met validation standards for selectivity, linearity, recovery, and precision, offering a practical tool for quality monitoring.  These findings expose a material entanglement between pet food production and fungal metabolite accumulation in supply chains serving herbivorous animals with limited regulatory oversight. The selective vulnerability of rabbits and rodents—whose gut microbiota can be disrupted by these toxins—reveals how emerging mycotoxins operate simultaneously as unmonitored contaminants and as agents that reshape the internal ecology of captive herbivores, creating new dependencies on feed quality assurance systems that currently do not exist. The contamination pattern across Bangkok's pet food markets suggests that the absence of routine monitoring does not indicate the absence of exposure, but rather the absence of institutional capacity to detect what is materially present.

title: Optimization and validation of a targeted high-throughput UHPLC-MS/MS method for the analysis of multiple mycotoxins in chicken serum, egg yolk and white
excerpt: Mycotoxins, produced by fungi, contaminate animal feed and subsequently enter food products like eggs, posing significant health risks. This study aimed to optimize and validate a sensitive, cost-efficient, high-throughput UHPLC-MS/MS method for the qualitative analysis of 38 mycotoxins, and the quantification of 30, 29 and 29 regulated and emerging mycotoxins in chicken serum, egg yolk and egg white, respectively. Sample preparation involved liquid extraction with 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile, followed by protein and phospholipid removal using Oasis® Ostro™. This high-throughput method processed 96 samples within 4 h. Chromatographic separation was performed on an Acquity Premier BEH C18 column using 0.1% acetic acid in both water and methanol as mobile phases, with gradient elution. The MS/MS instrument employed electrospray ionization polarity switching and operated in multiple reaction monitoring mode. To enhance performance, ¹³C-labeled internal standards were utilized.
